description: Students design a game or application where voice commands fully control the experience (no keyboard/mouse required). For example, a player says "jump," "left," or "right" to move and interact, promoting accessibility.

title: Build a chatbot that responds to voice and speaks back
short_name: Conversational voice bot
description: Students create a chatbot that listens (speech recognition), sends the recognized text to ChatGPT, receives a reply, and speaks it aloud (text-to-speech). This is a complete voice conversation cycle.

title: Detect and respond to exercise/fitness movements
short_name: Fitness game using body pose
description: Students use pose detection to identify when the player is doing a specific exercise (e.g., squat, jump, arm raise) and award points for correct form or repetitions. This combines movement detection with game scoring.

title: Log and analyze gesture data from a session
short_name: Record gesture data, analyze patterns
description: Students collect gesture/hand/pose data over time (position, finger angles, etc.) into a table during a gameplay or interaction session. They then analyze this data to answer questions (e.g., "What was the most common gesture?", "How much did the hand move?").

title: Design an interactive art piece controlled by voice and movement
short_name: Voice and gesture art installation
description: Students create an artistic project where speech input (e.g., words or emotions) and hand/body movements drive visual changes (colors, shapes, animations). The project is expressive and combines both modalities.

title: Handle speech recognition misheard words gracefully
short_name: Deal with speech recognition errors
description: Students implement error handling for speech recognition failures (e.g., when the system doesn't understand the word clearly). They add a confidence check or allow the user to retry if a word isn't recognized.

title: Evaluate fairness and bias in pose detection
short_name: Does pose detection work for everyone?
description: Students test pose detection on people with different body types, heights, abilities, and dress (e.g., loose vs tight clothing). They document whether the detection works equally well for everyone and reflect on potential bias.

title: Improve speech recognition with feedback loop
short_name: Learn from speech recognition mistakes
description: Students design a system that allows users to correct misheard words. Each correction is logged, helping the system (conceptually) improve over time. This introduces the idea of feedback-driven AI improvement.

title: Trace and understand hand detection data
short_name: Read and interpret hand data table
description: Students trace through the hand detection data table, understanding that each row represents a keypoint (finger joint) with coordinates, and each column is an attribute (x, y, z, angle). They select and use specific rows to answer questions about hand position and posture.

title: Design and test a hands-free app interface
short_name: Build a voice-controlled interface
description: Students design a small application (e.g., a quiz, a music player, a story reader) where all controls are voice-based. They test the interface with multiple users to evaluate how well voice commands are understood.

title: Combine multiple AI modalities (voice + vision) in one project
short_name: Multi-modal interaction
description: Students create a project that meaningfully uses both voice and vision (or gesture) at the same time, where each modality contributes distinct information (e.g., voice gives commands, vision confirms who is speaking or detects a pose to enable the command).

title: Measure and optimize gesture recognition accuracy
short_name: Test gesture accuracy
description: Students design a gesture (e.g., a thumbs-up, a specific hand shape, or pose) and test how consistently the system detects it. They measure accuracy (number of correct detections / total attempts) and try to improve it by refining the detection logic or providing clearer instructions to users.

title: Explain how AI voice/vision features affect user experience
short_name: Accessibility and inclusion with AI
description: Students reflect on how voice and vision recognition technologies enable or restrict access for different user groups (e.g., voice helps non-typists, but fails for those who are non-verbal; gesture recognition may miss people with limited mobility). They identify potential improvements.

title: Implement a complete voice-to-action pipeline with error handling
short_name: Robust voice command system
description: Students build a voice application that includes speech recognition, command parsing/matching, error handling for misheard words, and feedback to the user. The system is robust enough to handle real-world speech variations (e.g., "go left" vs "turn left").

title: Analyze pose data to classify or predict movement patterns
short_name: Predict movement from pose
description: Students collect pose data while a person performs different movements (e.g., walking, jumping, standing still) and use a table to organize and analyze the data. They look for patterns (e.g., differences in keypoint velocities, distances, or angles) that distinguish one movement from another.

title: Design and justify a voice/vision accessibility feature
short_name: Create an accessible feature
description: Students design a feature of an existing game or app that uses voice or vision to improve accessibility for a specific user group (e.g., a text-to-speech narrator for a reading game, hand-gesture controls for a player with limited fine motor control). They justify their design with evidence from user testing or accessibility research.

title: Evaluate and mitigate bias in AI detection systems
short_name: Test and reduce bias in AI
description: Students build or use a pose/gesture/speech detection system and systematically test it across different demographic groups, lighting conditions, accents, etc. They measure and document disparities in accuracy and propose mitigations.

title: Describe your project idea in a sentence
short_name: Explain your idea
description: Students articulate a complete (but simple) project idea in one or two sentences, including what the project does and who uses it (e.g., "I'm making a game where you click the cat to score points"). This develops clarity in communication before coding.

title: Ask XO for project ideas
short_name: Get ideas from XO
description: Students use XO (in structured conversation or guided prompts) to ask "Give me ideas for a project using [topic]" and receive suggestions. They learn that XO is a brainstorming partner and that AI can suggest multiple directions.

title: Ask for help starting a project
short_name: Ask XO for first steps
description: Once a student has a project idea, they ask XO "How do I start making a [project type]?" and receive a high-level outline (e.g., "First, draw your character. Then, add a button to start."). Students learn to ask sequential questions.

title: Decide when to ask XO: planning vs. coding
short_name: Know when to ask XO
description: Students distinguish between questions XO helps with (e.g., "What features should my game have?" or "How do I structure the code?") and questions better answered by trying (e.g., "Why doesn't this block work?" - better to debug directly). This teaches responsible use of AI as a guide, not a crutch.

title: Follow a multi-step plan from XO
short_name: Follow XO's project outline
description: Students receive a step-by-step plan from XO (e.g., 5 steps to make a game) and execute them in order, checking off each step as they complete it. This builds project management skills and shows that breaking a project into steps makes it manageable.

title: Rephrase a question if XO's answer doesn't help
short_name: Ask again if unclear
description: If a student asks XO "How do I make my sprite jump?" and the answer is too vague, they learn to rephrase it with more detail ("How do I make a sprite jump when I press the spacebar?") to get a more targeted response. This teaches iterative communication with AI.

title: Ask XO to review your code idea
short_name: Have XO check your plan
description: Before coding, a student describes their algorithm or plan to XO (e.g., "My plan is to repeat moving the sprite forward 10 times and then turn. Will this make a square?") and asks XO to spot issues or confirm it will work. This shifts XO use from brainstorming to validation.

title: Get improvement suggestions from XO, then decide
short_name: Ask for improvements, choose your own
description: After completing a simple project or feature, a student asks XO "What could I improve?" and receives suggestions (e.g., "You could add sound," "You could make the movement smoother," "You could add a title screen"). The student picks one improvement they want to make, reinforcing their agency.

title: Describe a bug to XO; try XO's suggestions before fixing it yourself
short_name: Use XO for debugging hints
description: When a student encounters a bug (e.g., "My sprite is stuck in a corner"), they describe it to XO (not paste full code, just explain) and ask for hints on what to check. XO might suggest "Check if you're resetting the position" or "Look at your loop condition." The student tries these hints. If a hint doesn't work, they continue debugging independently, learning that XO is a guide, not a solution.

title: Ask XO if your code is well-organized
short_name: Check code organization with XO
description: A student writes or pastes a short script and asks XO "Is this organized well?" or "Could I use a custom block here?" XO suggests refactoring opportunities. The student decides whether to adopt the suggestion based on understanding (not blind acceptance).

title: Discuss design choices with XO, then justify your decision
short_name: Explain why you coded it that way
description: After completing a project, a student asks XO "Why is my solution good?" or "Are there trade-offs I should know about?" XO explains pros and cons of the student's approach. The student then articulates their reasoning: "I used a loop because it's shorter" or "I used if/else because it's clearer to me." This reinforces that coding decisions involve values (clarity, efficiency, simplicity) and that the student's voice matters.

title: Recognize when XO doesn't know the answer
short_name: Know XO's limits
description: Students learn that XO sometimes gives generic answers or slightly incorrect suggestions, especially for CreatiCode-specific features or edge cases. They practice saying "That suggestion doesn't fit my project" or asking a peer/teacher instead. This builds critical thinking and prevents over-reliance on AI.

title: Ask XO about algorithm efficiency
short_name: Compare solutions with XO
description: Given multiple ways to solve a problem (e.g., two different loop structures, two different variable organizations), a student asks XO "Which is better and why?" XO explains trade-offs (clarity vs. speed, etc.). The student then decides based on their project needs.

title: Create a project plan with XO, then document your decisions
short_name: Plan and document with XO
description: A student asks XO for a detailed project plan (e.g., all steps to make a platformer game), receives the outline, follows it while taking notes on why they chose each step or what they changed. They then write a brief project report documenting their decisions and how they differ from XO's suggestion.

title: Combine feedback from XO, peer, and your own testing
short_name: Use multiple feedback sources
description: After completing a feature or project, a student gathers feedback from XO ("What do you think of this?"), a peer ("Does it work well?"), and their own testing ("Does it do what I want?"). They analyze all three inputs and decide what to change based on their priorities.

title: Recognize bias or limitations in XO's suggestions
short_name: Think critically about XO advice
description: Students learn that XO may favor certain approaches (e.g., always suggest a loop even when if/else is simpler, or not know about CreatiCode-specific blocks). They practice saying "This suggestion doesn't fit my project" and explaining why. This builds metacognitive awareness.

title: Ask XO for algorithm design help
short_name: Design algorithms with XO
description: Given a complex task (e.g., "How do I search a list for a value?"), a student asks XO for a conceptual outline or pseudocode, not full code. XO provides steps. The student implements it and documents where their code came from. This combines AI assistance with student problem-solving.

title: Cross-check XO advice with documentation or peers
short_name: Verify XO's suggestions
description: When XO suggests a solution, a student learns to verify it: "Does the CreatiCode docs say this is right?" or "Does this match what my peer said?" This prevents adopting incorrect or outdated advice.

title: Ask XO to explain code and assess the explanation
short_name: Get code explanations from XO
description: A student pastes a short script (their own or a peer's) and asks XO "What does this do?" XO explains the logic. The student assesses: "Is that right?" by tracing the code or testing it. If there's a mismatch, they ask a follow-up question or correct XO.

title: Balance XO assistance with peer collaboration and independent work
short_name: Use XO alongside peers and solo work
description: Students learn that a healthy project workflow includes asking XO (for big ideas), collaborating with peers (for diverse perspectives), and working alone (for deep understanding). They practice deciding which mode to use when.

title: Ask XO about edge cases and robustness
short_name: Plan for edge cases with XO
description: Before or after implementing a solution, a student asks XO "What edge cases might break my code?" or "How do I make my solution more robust?" XO suggests cases (negative numbers, empty lists, etc.). The student tests or implements guards against them.

title: Discuss trade-offs: speed vs. clarity with XO
short_name: Evaluate design trade-offs
description: Students understand that many coding decisions involve trade-offs (a loop is faster but a function call is clearer; a variable is flexible but a constant is predictable). They ask XO "Which is better for my goal?" and make informed choices based on their priorities.

title: Use XO to refactor and improve existing code
short_name: Ask XO for refactoring ideas
description: After completing a working solution, a student shows it to XO and asks "How could I make this better?" XO suggests refactoring (extract a function, use a data structure, simplify a condition). The student implements one or two suggestions and documents why.

title: Critique XO's suggestions against your priorities
short_name: Evaluate whether XO's idea fits your project
description: XO might suggest a sophisticated optimization or feature that's technically sound but doesn't align with a student's project goals (e.g., XO suggests a complex sorting algorithm when the student's list is tiny, or XO suggests a 3D feature when the project is 2D). Students learn to say "That's smart, but not what I need for this project" and explain why.

title: Use XO to help document a complex project
short_name: Generate documentation with XO
description: After completing a multi-feature project, a student shows XO the code and asks "Help me write clear documentation for a peer to understand this." XO provides a structured outline (overview, features, code breakdown). The student refines it with their own details and perspective, creating a hybrid human-AI document.

title: Reflect on your coding decisions with XO's help
short_name: Use XO for self-reflection
description: A student completes a project and asks XO "What strengths do you see in my code?" or "What would I improve if I had more time?" XO provides feedback. The student integrates this with their own self-assessment ("I was proud that I used a loop to reduce repetition. Next time, I'd…").

title: Ask XO to help debug by explaining your hypothesis
short_name: Use XO to test debugging theories
description: Before diving into code, a student tells XO their hypothesis about a bug ("I think the sprite is stuck because the loop never ends"). XO helps them design a test (add a print statement, add a timer, etc.). The student tests and reports back. This combines logical reasoning with AI-assisted verification.

title: Recognize and mitigate limitations of XO-assisted code
short_name: Verify XO code quality
description: Sometimes XO-generated code or suggestions work but aren't ideal (inefficient, unclear, not fully correct). Grade 8 students learn to review code XO suggests, test it thoroughly, and either adopt it with understanding or revise it. They practice the principle: "AI is a tool, not an authority."

title: Collect and sort data by simple categories
short_name: Collect and organize data
description: Students gather simple data from classmates or classroom objects (e.g., favorite colors, pets owned, breakfast foods) and organize it into categories or groups, recognizing that data can be organized in different ways.

title: Compare numbers as "more," "less," or "same"
short_name: Compare quantities
description: Students compare two groups of objects or two numeric values using words like "more," "fewer," and "equal," developing a sense of numeric comparison.

title: Recognize that numbers have special meaning
short_name: Understand what numbers tell us
description: Students learn that numbers convey specific information (age, count, score, temperature) and that the same numeral can mean different things in different contexts (3 years old vs. score of 3).

title: Create a simple tally or picture chart
short_name: Make a chart of information
description: Students create a simple visual record of collected data (tally marks, pictures in rows) to show the information more clearly. This introduces the idea of data visualization.

title: Compare numeric and non‑numeric data types
short_name: What data type is this?
description: Students identify and classify data as either numeric (numbers: age, score, quantity) or non‑numeric/categorical (words or categories: color, name, type of food).

title: Create a variable to store a single piece of data
short_name: Make a variable and store a value
description: Students learn to create a CreatiCode variable (e.g., `my score`, `favorite color`) and assign it a value, understanding that a variable is a named container for information.

title: Identify when data is numeric vs. constant
short_name: Does this value change?
description: Students distinguish between constant values (e.g., a name, a fixed color choice) and values that change over time (e.g., score, age, temperature).

title: Use a variable to track changing information
short_name: Update a variable's value
description: Students modify a variable's value as a program runs (e.g., increasing a score, updating a timer), understanding that variables allow us to keep track of information that changes.

title: Organize collected data into a simple table
short_name: Put data in a table
description: Students collect data (e.g., students' favorite foods) and organize it into a simple two‑column table (item and count or name and choice), understanding tables as an organized way to show data.

title: Understand accuracy and completeness in data
short_name: Is this data correct and complete?
description: Students evaluate collected data to check if it is accurate (correct values) and complete (no missing entries), learning that data quality matters.

title: Create a survey and collect data systematically
short_name: Design and run a survey
description: Students plan a simple survey (picking a clear question, deciding on answer choices), run it with classmates, and collect the responses systematically.

title: Distinguish between different data types in a program
short_name: Name the data types in code
description: Students read a simple program and identify the data types of variables used (e.g., `score` is a number, `name` is text), understanding that different kinds of information need different storage.

title: Use true/false values to record simple facts
short_name: Store yes/no answers
description: Students create or use a variable that stores a true/false (boolean) value, such as `is playing` or `has coin`, learning that some information is naturally yes/no.

title: Build a data structure with a list
short_name: Create and use a list
description: Students create a list (or array) in CreatiCode and add items to it (e.g., a list of high scores, a list of item names), understanding lists as a way to store multiple related values.

title: Represent data in a table with rows and columns
short_name: Organize data in a table
description: Students create or work with tables where rows represent individual records (e.g., a person) and columns represent attributes (e.g., name, age, favorite color). This is foundational for understanding structured data.

title: Understand simple binary representation
short_name: Encode information as on/off
description: Students explore the idea that information can be encoded using just two states (on/off, 1/0, true/false), laying groundwork for understanding how computers store data.

title: Trace how data flows through a program
short_name: Follow data through a program
description: Students read a short program and trace how a piece of data (e.g., user input, a variable) enters, is modified, and produces an output, understanding data as information flowing through code.

title: Store and retrieve data from a list by position
short_name: Access items in a list
description: Students use list operations to add, remove, or access items at specific positions in a list, understanding lists as ordered collections.

title: Convert between data representations
short_name: Change how data is displayed
description: Students transform data from one format to another (e.g., from a numeric count to a word description, from individual values to a list) to use information in different ways.

title: Use multiple data types in a single program
short_name: Mix number, text, boolean, and list types
description: Students design a program that uses several data types together (e.g., player name as text, score as a number, items collected as a list, is playing as boolean) to represent a complete scenario.

title: Create and manipulate a table of records
short_name: Use a table to store structured data
description: Students use CreatiCode's table variable to store multiple records (e.g., a leaderboard with names and scores, a game inventory with items and quantities), accessing and updating specific fields.

title: Understand different ways to encode the same data
short_name: Binary, decimal, and symbol encoding
description: Students explore how the same information can be represented in different ways (e.g., the number 5 in decimal, 101 in binary, or ***** as a tally), understanding encoding choices.

title: Design a simple data collection system
short_name: Plan data collection for a project
description: Students design what data they need to collect for a project (e.g., game times, player choices, sensor readings) and plan how to store and organize it.

title: Convert a program to use lists instead of multiple variables
short_name: Refactor using lists or tables
description: Students take a program that uses many similar variables (e.g., `score1`, `score2`, `score3`) and refactor it to use a single list or table instead, reducing duplication and improving clarity.

title: Examine data types and their properties
short_name: Identify properties of different data types
description: Students understand what values each data type can hold and why certain types are appropriate for certain tasks (numbers for quantities, text for names, booleans for states, lists for collections).

title: Work with local and cloud-backed variables
short_name: Understand local vs. shared variables
description: Students learn that variables can be local (only within a sprite or script) or shared/cloud-backed (accessible to multiple sprites or across sessions), understanding when each type is appropriate.

title: Create metadata describing a dataset
short_name: Document what your data means
description: Students write simple metadata for a dataset they collect (e.g., "This list contains student names from Grade 6. Collected on [date]"). This prepares them to understand data context.

title: Filter and organize data using computational tools
short_name: Sort and filter data
description: Students use CreatiCode blocks (or similar tools) to filter a list or table (e.g., show only high scores, show only red items) and sort data (e.g., alphabetical, numerical), understanding how the same data can be viewed in different ways.

title: Distinguish between nominal, ordinal, and numeric data
short_name: Categorize data by how it's organized
description: Students classify data as nominal (categories with no order, like colors), ordinal (categories with order, like T-shirt sizes), or numeric (continuous or discrete numbers), understanding how data type affects analysis.

title: Represent numbers at different precision levels
short_name: Understand precision in numeric data
description: Students explore how the precision of numeric data affects storage and meaning (e.g., rounding 3.14159 to 3.14, storing temperature to the nearest degree vs. tenth), understanding trade-offs.

title: Use nested data structures to represent complex information
short_name: Store complex data in lists and tables
description: Students create or work with nested structures (e.g., a list of tables, where each table represents a player with multiple attributes) to model real-world complexity.

title: Evaluate the appropriateness of a data type for a task
short_name: Pick the right data type
description: Students analyze a project scenario and make evidence-based decisions about what data types to use, considering what operations will be needed and what values are expected.

title: Handle missing or invalid data in a program
short_name: Deal with incomplete or wrong data
description: Students write code that gracefully handles missing values (e.g., a player with no high score) or invalid input, understanding data quality issues.

title: Compare storage and efficiency of different data representations
short_name: Choose efficient ways to store data
description: Students compare two ways of representing the same information (e.g., storing 5 items as individual variables vs. a list, or as a single tally number) and reason about efficiency and clarity.

title: Design a complete data schema for a project
short_name: Plan your data structure
description: Students design a detailed plan for what data a project will store, including all variable types, relationships, and constraints (e.g., "score must be non-negative," "player name is required").

title: Recognize bias and limitations in data representation
short_name: Think critically about how data is encoded
description: Students explore how choices in data representation can introduce bias or lose important information (e.g., representing gender as only "boy" or "girl," categorizing ages into broad ranges, using single-language labels).

title: Use advanced data structures for algorithms
short_name: Choose data structures for efficiency
description: Students select appropriate data structures (lists, tables, or dictionaries) for an algorithmic task, understanding that the choice affects how efficiently the program can search, sort, or process data.

title: Explore how data type mismatches cause errors
short_name: Debug data type errors
description: Students encounter and fix programs where incorrect operations are performed on wrong data types (e.g., adding the text "5" to the number 10, or trying to sort mixed data types incorrectly), understanding type constraints.

title: Evaluate how data representation affects real-world decisions
short_name: Understand data representation's impact
description: Students analyze real-world scenarios where data representation choices have consequences (e.g., how credit scores are calculated, how student grades are recorded, how census categories are defined) and discuss ethical implications.

title: Collect data by asking a question
short_name: Ask and collect responses
description: Students pose a simple yes/no or one-of-few-choices question (e.g., "Do you like apples or oranges?" "What is your favorite color: red, blue, or yellow?") to peers and collect their answers by marking or listing responses. This connects asking a question to gathering information.

title: Compare two groups of data
short_name: Which group has more?
description: Students collect two small datasets (e.g., favorite colors from boys and girls, or scores from two games) and compare them to answer simple questions (which has more, which is smaller, etc.). This introduces the idea that comparing data can reveal patterns.

title: Make a simple list from collected data
short_name: Keep a list of collected items
description: Students collect information about a small set of items (e.g., names of three favorite snacks, types of plants in the classroom) and create a simple list by writing or selecting items. This builds familiarity with lists as an organizing structure.

title: Collect data through observation and measurement
short_name: Observe and measure
description: Students collect data by observing or measuring something (e.g., plant heights over time, number of steps to cross the room, sound volume in different parts of the classroom) using simple tools or counting. This introduces the idea that data can come from direct observation as well as surveys.

title: Organize data into a simple table
short_name: Make a data table (rows and columns)
description: Students take collected data points and organize them into a table with rows and columns, where each row represents one record and each column represents an attribute (e.g., a table of "Student Name" and "Number of Books Read"). This is the first structured data organization beyond simple lists.

title: Use a survey to collect class data
short_name: Run a simple survey
description: Students design and administer a very simple survey (one question with a few preset response options, e.g., "What is your favorite pet: dog, cat, fish, or bird?") to the class and record all responses. This introduces survey methodology in a hands-on way.

title: Recognize missing or incomplete data
short_name: Find gaps in collected data
description: Students are shown a dataset with some missing values or incomplete entries and identify which pieces are missing (e.g., a table where some cells are blank, or a list where a response says "skip"). This builds awareness of data quality.

title: Collaborate to collect consistent data
short_name: Collect data as a team with a procedure
description: Students work together to collect data following a clear procedure (e.g., all students measure height the same way, or all tally observations using the same categories). They understand that consistent methods help ensure reliable data.

title: Evaluate data for accuracy and completeness
short_name: Check data quality
description: Students examine a dataset and identify problems such as duplicates, out-of-range values, missing entries, or inconsistent units (e.g., some temperatures in Celsius and some in Fahrenheit). They evaluate whether the data is trustworthy.

title: Organize data in a labeled table with multiple columns
short_name: Build a multi-attribute table
description: Students take collected data and organize it into a table with multiple columns representing different attributes (e.g., a table with columns for "Plant Name", "Height in cm", "Days to Sprout", "Color"). Each row is one record. This extends the Grade 2 skill to handle richer, more realistic data.

title: Retrieve and use data from a created list or table
short_name: Read data from a list or table
description: Students write code to access specific pieces of data from a list (e.g., the name of a student at position 3) or table (e.g., the height of the plant in row 2) using index or item-access blocks. This introduces programming with structured data.

title: Design and conduct a survey with a clear question
short_name: Design a survey
description: Students formulate a data question they want to answer (e.g., "What is the most popular sport?") and design a survey with multiple-choice response options. They administer it and record all responses. This introduces intentional survey design.

title: Log events in a game using a counter or list
short_name: Track game events with variables or lists
description: Students build a simple game or interactive project where a variable or list is used to record events that happen (e.g., every time a coin is collected, the count increases; every time a button is pressed, a record is added to a list). The log grows as the game runs.

title: Create metadata for a dataset
short_name: Document what your data is
description: Students create a brief written description of a dataset they collected: what was measured, how it was measured, when, and by whom. This is the beginning of understanding metadata.

title: Spot patterns in organized data
short_name: Find patterns in tables or lists
description: Students examine an organized dataset (table or list) and identify simple patterns or trends (e.g., "More students chose red than blue", "Plant A grew taller than Plant B", "Scores increased each round"). This is early data interpretation.

title: Collect data using sensors or automated methods
short_name: Use sensors or timers to collect data
description: Students create a program that uses CreatiCode's built-in reporters (like timer, loudness, mouse position, or simulated sensors) to automatically collect numeric data over time, storing results in a list or table. This introduces automated data logging.

title: Organize complex data into a table structure
short_name: Build and structure a table with rules
description: Students organize a more complex, real-world dataset (20+ records with 4+ columns) into a properly structured table, with clear headers and consistent data types in each column (e.g., all numeric, all text, etc.). This reinforces table structure and data consistency.

title: Filter or sort data by a rule
short_name: Sort or filter data in a table
description: Students use code blocks or table operations to sort data (e.g., scores from highest to lowest) or filter it (e.g., show only students with scores above 80) to help answer a data question. This introduces basic data processing.

title: Compare collected data sets to find differences
short_name: Compare two datasets
description: Students collect (or are given) two similar datasets (e.g., favorite foods from boys vs. girls, temperature readings from morning vs. afternoon) and compare them to draw simple conclusions (e.g., which group preferred pizza more, when was it warmer).

title: Save or export collected data
short_name: Store data for later use
description: Students create a simple mechanism to save their collected data so it persists (using a variable, a list in the project, or a simple cloud block if available) rather than losing it when the program stops. This introduces the idea of data persistence.

title: Design a data collection plan for a research question
short_name: Plan a data investigation
description: Students articulate a research question (e.g., "Do students exercise more on weekdays or weekends?" or "Which school lunch option is most popular?"), decide what data to collect, how to collect it, from whom, and how many samples to gather. They write or present a simple data collection plan.

title: Execute a multi-method data collection using surveys and observations
short_name: Collect data from surveys and observations
description: Students conduct a small data collection involving both a survey (asking questions) and observational data (e.g., counting or measuring). They combine results from both sources into one dataset.

title: Share data across users using multiplayer or cloud blocks
short_name: Share data with classmates
description: Students create a shared data collection where multiple users can contribute data (e.g., a shared scorekeeper, or each student adding their survey response to a cloud list). They use CreatiCode's multiplayer or cloud variable blocks to sync data.

title: Organize and document a dataset with metadata
short_name: Create a complete dataset with documentation
description: Students take collected data and organize it into a CreatiCode table with clear column headers, consistent formatting, and write a brief metadata document describing the data (what was measured, by whom, when, units, any known limitations).

title: Clean and prepare data for analysis
short_name: Fix data problems before analyzing
description: Students identify issues in a collected dataset (missing values, inconsistent units, typos, duplicates) and apply simple fixes: filling in missing entries, standardizing units, removing duplicates, or noting problematic rows. They create a "cleaned" version.

title: Formulate a clear, testable data question
short_name: Ask a data-driven question
description: Students formulate a specific data question that can be answered by collecting and analyzing data, distinguishing it from questions answered by opinion or general knowledge. Examples: "Do taller students jump higher?" "Which type of music gets the most plays in our class?"

title: Collect data systematically using lists and tables
short_name: Conduct a data collection campaign
description: Students execute a planned data collection (20-50 data points across 3-4 columns), recording data into a CreatiCode table or list. They maintain data quality by following consistent procedures.

title: Manipulate data with code (filter, sort, aggregate)
short_name: Process data using loops and conditions
description: Students write code that reads from a table or list, applies filters (keep only rows where a condition is true) or sorts (arrange by a column), or calculates aggregates (sum, average, count) to prepare data for analysis.

title: Identify and correct data quality issues
short_name: Debug and repair data
description: Students systematically review collected data, identify specific quality issues (duplicates, out-of-range values, inconsistent units, missing entries), and apply appropriate fixes. They document what was wrong and how they fixed it.

title: Draw simple conclusions from organized data
short_name: Interpret data to answer questions
description: Students examine their collected and cleaned dataset and use it to answer the original data question. They identify the most common value, the largest/smallest, trends, or comparisons between groups, and state a simple conclusion.

title: Design an ethical data collection process
short_name: Plan ethical data practices
description: Students design a data collection for a research question while considering ethical issues: privacy (what personal data is necessary), consent (asking permission to collect data), fairness (including diverse participants, avoiding bias), and transparency (telling people what their data will be used for).

title: Execute a complete data investigation (question to analysis)
short_name: Conduct a full data investigation
description: Students execute an end-to-end data investigation: ask a testable question, collect 30-100 data points across multiple attributes, organize into a table, clean the data, filter/aggregate as needed, analyze to answer the question, and write a brief summary of findings and any limitations.

title: Analyze relationships between variables in data
short_name: Find connections between data columns
description: Students work with a multi-column dataset and analyze relationships between variables (e.g., "Do students who read more books also have higher vocabulary scores?" or "Is there a pattern between hours of screen time and sleep quality?"). They use filtering, sorting, or visual inspection to identify patterns.

title: Recognize bias and limitations in data collection
short_name: Spot bias and limitations
description: Students examine a dataset or a data collection process and identify potential biases (e.g., sampling only from one school excludes other communities, asking questions on an app excludes people without internet) and limitations (e.g., small sample size, measurements taken at only one time). They reflect on how these affect conclusions.

title: Use cloud storage or multiplayer data to conduct group research
short_name: Collaborate on shared data
description: Students work in a group to collect data where each member contributes to a shared table or list (using CreatiCode's cloud or multiplayer blocks), then collectively analyze the combined dataset. This introduces collaborative data science and networked data collection.

title: Collect and count data on a simple survey
short_name: Ask a question and count answers
description: Students ask a simple yes/no or multiple-choice question of a few peers (e.g., "Do you like apples or oranges?") and record tally marks or objects to represent each answer. They then count the totals for each option, building skills in data collection and organization.

title: Create a simple pictograph
short_name: Make a picture chart of data
description: Students represent collected data (e.g., favorite fruits, pets, or colors) using a pictograph where each picture stands for one response. They arrange pictures or icons in rows or columns to display the data visually.

title: Answer simple questions using counts
short_name: Use counts to answer "How many?"
description: Given a pictograph or tally display that students created or are shown, they answer simple counting questions: "How many people like blue?" or "Which color do the most people like?"

title: Create a simple bar chart
short_name: Build a bar chart from data
description: Students take collected data (e.g., classroom survey responses) and create a bar chart using blocks or a template in CreatiCode. The chart displays categories horizontally or vertically with heights corresponding to counts.

title: Predict the mode or highest count
short_name: Which group has the most?
description: Students read a bar chart (pictograph or drawn bars) and determine which category has the highest count (the mode), strengthening data interpretation skills.

title: Compare data using "more," "fewer," "about the same"
short_name: Compare two groups using counts
description: Students compare the counts for two groups (e.g., "Does blue have more or fewer votes than red?") and use appropriate language ("more," "fewer," "about the same") to describe the relationship.

title: Find the total by adding counts
short_name: Add up data to find a total
description: Students are given counts for several categories and compute the total (e.g., "There are 3 cats, 2 dogs, and 4 birds. How many animals altogether?"). This introduces simple aggregation.

title: Calculate the average of a small dataset
short_name: Find the average (mean)
description: Students compute the mean of 3–5 small numbers (e.g., test scores, tallies of favorite colors) by adding them up and dividing by how many items there are. This introduces the concept of a summary statistic.

title: Create a labeled bar or line chart
short_name: Draw a chart with titles and labels
description: Students construct a bar or line chart in CreatiCode that includes a title, axis labels (e.g., "Favorite Color," "Number of Votes"), and properly scaled bars or points. This emphasizes that a good data visualization is clear and complete.

title: Identify an outlier in a dataset
short_name: Spot a value that doesn't fit the pattern
description: Students examine a dataset (displayed as a chart, list, or sequence) and identify a value that is notably higher or lower than the others (an outlier), and describe why it might be different (e.g., "One student read way more books than the others").

title: Describe a simple trend
short_name: See how data changes over time
description: Students look at a line chart or sequence of bar charts showing data over multiple time periods (e.g., daily temperature, number of followers over a week) and describe whether values are going up, down, or staying about the same.

title: Calculate the mode and median
short_name: Find the mode and median of data
description: Students compute the mode (most common value) and median (middle value when data is ordered) for datasets of 5–10 items. These are alternative measures of "typical value" that complement the mean.

title: Compare two datasets using averages
short_name: Which group is typical higher or lower?
description: Students compute averages (means) for two groups and compare them (e.g., "Class A read an average of 8 books; Class B read an average of 6 books. Which class read more on average?"). This applies averages to meaningful comparison.

title: Create a visualization that highlights a relationship
short_name: Show how two pieces of information connect
description: Students create a data visualization (e.g., a scatter plot or grouped bar chart) that displays two variables together, such as height vs age or study time vs test score. They may not yet compute correlation but begin to see patterns in relationships.

title: Identify and fix a data error
short_name: Find and correct bad data
description: Students examine a dataset that contains an obvious error (e.g., a missing value, a mistyped number, a duplicate entry) and either correct it or note why it should be removed. This introduces data-quality thinking.

title: Use a loop to count or aggregate data
short_name: Use a loop to add up or count data
description: Students write a loop (e.g., `repeat for each item in list`) that iterates through a dataset, maintains a count or sum variable, and reports the result. This applies loop skills to data aggregation.

title: Compute average, min, and max of a list
short_name: Find average, minimum, and maximum values
description: Students use loops and conditional blocks to compute summary statistics for a list: the mean, the smallest value (minimum), and the largest value (maximum). These are fundamental aggregation operations.

title: Create a multi-variable bar or line chart
short_name: Build a chart with multiple series
description: Students create a visualization showing multiple related variables (e.g., monthly rainfall and temperature side by side, or scores from multiple students over several rounds). This requires careful positioning and potentially different colors or grouping.

title: Describe variability and outliers in context
short_name: Explain differences and unusual values in data
description: Students examine a dataset and describe its variability (how spread out values are) and any outliers, connecting these observations to real-world context (e.g., "Most students read 5–10 books, but one student read 30 because they love reading").

title: Filter data by one or more attributes
short_name: Select rows that match a condition
description: Students use a computational tool or CreatiCode loops with conditionals to filter a dataset, keeping only rows that match a criterion (e.g., "show only people over 10 years old" or "show only red apples"). This introduces subsetting and focused analysis.

title: Group data and compute group summaries
short_name: Split data into groups and analyze each
description: Students organize a dataset by categories (e.g., group by color, by age range) and compute separate summaries for each group (e.g., total, average, count per group). This is a fundamental grouping and aggregation operation.

title: Identify relationships between variables
short_name: See how two variables relate
description: Students analyze a dataset with multiple variables and describe or identify patterns: do two variables tend to increase together, or does one decrease while the other increases? (E.g., "Students who study more tend to score higher.") This is correlation reasoning without formal computation.

title: Evaluate visualization clarity and design choices
short_name: Critique a data visualization
description: Students examine a data visualization and evaluate its design: Is the title clear? Are axes labeled? Are colors used effectively? Does the chart accurately represent the data? Students provide constructive feedback on design choices.

title: Simulate data collection and compute statistics
short_name: Run simulations and analyze the results
description: Students create a loop-based simulation (e.g., simulating a chance experiment, rolling dice, or surveying random responses) and track results in a list or tally variables. They then analyze the simulated data (compute average, count outcomes) to estimate probabilities or expected values.

title: Identify and describe bias in data collection
short_name: Spot bias in how data was collected
description: Students examine a data-collection scenario (e.g., a survey conducted only at recess, a sample that doesn't represent everyone) and identify potential sources of bias. They explain how bias might skew the results.

title: Analyze trends over time and make predictions
short_name: Follow trends to predict future values
description: Students examine a time-series chart (e.g., daily temperature, monthly website visits, population growth) and describe the trend. They then make a reasonable prediction about what will happen next (e.g., "The temperature has been rising each day; it will probably rise again tomorrow").

title: Compare distributions of data
short_name: Compare shape and spread of two datasets
description: Students compare two datasets (e.g., two classes' test scores, rainfall in two cities) by looking at their distributions: shape (skew, symmetry), center (mean or median), and spread (range, variability). They describe which dataset is more consistent or has more extreme values.

title: Design and conduct a simple data investigation
short_name: Ask a question, collect, analyze, and conclude
description: Students develop a data question, design a collection method, gather data using CreatiCode (e.g., a survey project, simulation, or sensor logging), organize and analyze the data (computing summaries and visualizations), and write a conclusion supported by the data.

title: Analyze two variables for potential causal relationships
short_name: Explore whether one variable affects another
description: Students investigate whether a relationship between two variables suggests causation (e.g., does study time cause higher test scores?) or is merely correlation. They consider alternative explanations and limitations of the data.

title: Create an interactive data dashboard
short_name: Build a tool to explore data with controls
description: Students use CreatiCode widgets (sliders, buttons, dropdowns) to build an interactive dashboard that displays filtered or grouped data, allowing users to adjust parameters and see updated visualizations. This combines data analysis with UI design.

title: Evaluate and justify data-driven conclusions
short_name: Support a conclusion with data evidence
description: Students examine a data-driven conclusion or argument (e.g., "Our school should extend recess because students are happier") and evaluate it critically: Is the data sufficient? Is the conclusion justified? What alternative explanations exist? What data would strengthen or weaken the argument?

title: Recognize "more likely" and "less likely"
short_name: Is it more or less likely?
description: Students compare simple probability scenarios informally (e.g., picking a red ball from a bag with 5 red and 1 blue vs. a bag with 3 red and 3 blue) and decide which outcome is "more likely" or "less likely," building qualitative probability reasoning.

title: Perform and record a simple chance experiment
short_name: Run an experiment and keep score
description: Students physically perform a simple chance experiment (e.g., flip a coin, spin a spinner) multiple times and use tally marks or pictures to record each outcome, introducing data collection in the context of chance.

title: Compare predictions to actual results
short_name: Did you guess right?
description: Before running an experiment, students make a prediction (e.g., "I think the coin will land on heads 5 times out of 10"); they then perform the experiment and compare their prediction to the actual results, introducing the idea that predictions are not always correct.

title: Use a loop to run many trials
short_name: Run an experiment 20 times with a loop
description: Students use a `repeat` loop in code to simulate a chance event (e.g., coin flip or die roll) many times automatically, avoiding manual repetition and introducing the connection between loops (T07) and data collection.

title: Create a tally or count from experiment results
short_name: Count heads and tails
description: After running an experiment (manually or in code), students create a tally chart, count, or list to show how many times each outcome occurred, building data organization and summary skills.

title: Recognize patterns in repeated experiments
short_name: Run the experiment twice and compare
description: Students run the same chance experiment twice (or look at results from two trials) and notice that results differ each time, even with the same rules. This builds intuition that randomness produces variability.

title: Introduce the idea of a "fair game"
short_name: Is this a fair game?
description: Students play or simulate simple games with chance and evaluate whether the game is "fair" (all players have equal chance to win) or "unfair" (one player has an advantage). They may compare experimental outcomes to justify their reasoning.

title: Simulate an experiment 50+ times to see a pattern
short_name: Run many trials to spot the trend
description: Students write code to run a simulation a larger number of times (50–100 trials) using a loop and accumulator variables, allowing them to observe stabilizing frequencies and patterns in randomness over larger sample sizes.

title: Compare frequencies from two different experiments
short_name: Is coin or die more likely to land on one side?
description: Students run two different chance experiments (e.g., coin flip vs. spinner with unequal sections) and compare the frequencies to reason about which outcome is more likely based on empirical data from their simulations.

title: Plan a simple survey with clear questions
short_name: Write a survey question
description: Students design a simple survey question (e.g., "What is your favorite color?") to collect data from classmates or a simulated population, learning that data can come from observation or asking people, and that question clarity matters.

title: Recognize sampling bias and its effect
short_name: Is your sample fair?
description: Students examine a hypothetical experiment or survey where the sample is biased (e.g., "Ask only kids in the library about favorite recess activity") and reason about why the results might not represent the whole group. This introduces the concept of bias without requiring formal statistical language.

title: Calculate theoretical probability from a model
short_name: What should happen in theory?
description: Given a clear model (e.g., a die with 6 equal sides, or a bag with 3 red and 2 blue marbles), students calculate or reason about the theoretical probability of an outcome (e.g., "1 in 6 chance for each number") and express it as a ratio or simple fraction.

title: Compare experimental results to theoretical probability
short_name: Do your results match the prediction?
description: Students run a simulation with a known theoretical probability (e.g., rolling a fair die 60 times and expecting each number ~10 times) and compare their observed frequency to the theoretical expectation, building reasoning about variability and sample size.

title: Run a weighted or unequal probability simulation
short_name: Simulate a spinner with unequal sections
description: Students code a simulation where probabilities are unequal (e.g., a spinner with one large section and one small section, or a weighted die), using conditional logic or random ranges to encode the different probabilities.

title: Collect survey data responsibly and discuss privacy
short_name: Plan a survey and respect privacy
description: Students design a survey for peers or a community, addressing privacy concerns such as: What information is necessary to collect? How will responses be stored? Who will see the results? This connects data collection to ethics and privacy awareness.

title: Design a realistic simulation (e.g., weather, sports)
short_name: Build a simulation with probabilities
description: Students design and code a simulation of a real-world scenario (e.g., daily weather patterns, a sports match outcome) that uses random events and accumulator variables to model the scenario over many iterations, integrating loops, variables, and randomness.

title: Estimate a probability from observed data
short_name: Guess the probability from the data
description: Given results from a large number of trials (from code or from a provided dataset), students estimate the probability of an outcome by calculating the frequency (e.g., "47 successes out of 100 trials means about 47% chance"), building the connection between frequency and probability.

title: Identify how sample size affects frequency stability
short_name: Does 10 trials match 100 trials?
description: Students run the same simulation with two different sample sizes (e.g., 10 trials vs. 100 trials) and compare the frequency distributions, observing that larger samples produce more stable (less variable) frequency estimates.

title: Analyze bias in a simulated or real experiment
short_name: Find the flaw in the experiment
description: Students examine a described or simulated experiment with a flaw or bias (e.g., "Only survey kids who like sports to find out if kids like sports") and reason about how the flaw would affect the results, building critical analysis of experimental design.

title: Design a controlled experiment with random sampling
short_name: Design an experiment with controls
description: Students plan a controlled experiment (e.g., testing if plant growth is affected by light) that includes identifying variables to control, identifying what to measure, and planning to collect data fairly from a random sample. This moves from simulation to real-world experimental design.

title: Run a simulation and analyze variability in results
short_name: Run the simulation multiple times and see the spread
description: Students code a complete simulation (building on grade 5) and run it multiple times, each time obtaining slightly different results due to randomness. They analyze the distribution of outcomes across runs to understand variability.

title: Use computational tools to identify relationships among variables
short_name: Find which variable affects the outcome
description: Students use a provided dataset or run a simulation that has multiple input variables, and use filtering, sorting, or conditional analysis in code or tools to identify which variable most affects the outcome (e.g., "Does rain always come after clouds?").

title: Evaluate fairness of a game or sampling process
short_name: Is this game or survey fair?
description: Students analyze a game, survey, or experimental procedure and judge whether all possible outcomes or participants have an equal (fair) or unequal (biased) chance of being included or winning. They may use simulation or logical reasoning to support their judgment.

title: Conduct a full multi-step experiment with hypothesis
short_name: Test a hypothesis with an experiment
description: Students formulate a clear hypothesis (prediction), design an experiment to test it (with controls, variables, and sample size decisions), collect data, and draw conclusions, practicing the scientific method within a probability or observational context.

title: Implement a Monte Carlo simulation to estimate a probability
short_name: Run 1000s of trials to estimate odds
description: Students code a simulation using a large number of iterations (e.g., 1000 or 10,000 trials) to empirically estimate a complex probability (e.g., chance of rolling three dice that sum to 10, or chance of at least two people sharing a birthday in a room of 20). They interpret the frequency as a probability estimate.

title: Analyze sources of bias in data collection and its impact
short_name: How did bias affect the results?
description: Students examine a real or simulated dataset known to have bias (e.g., results from a survey taken only online, results from a controlled experiment run only in one location), analyze how the bias occurred, and reason about how the results would differ if the bias were eliminated.

title: Conduct a sampling experiment and compare to population parameter
short_name: Does your sample match the whole group?
description: Students take multiple random samples from a known population (real or simulated), compute a statistic (e.g., mean, proportion) for each sample, and compare sample statistics to the true population parameter, building intuition about sampling variability and estimators.

title: Design and conduct an experiment addressing a real question
short_name: Run an experiment to answer your question
description: Students develop their own research question, design an experiment or survey to answer it (including decisions about variables, controls, sample size, and data collection method), conduct the experiment, analyze results, and communicate findings. This is a capstone skill integrating earlier concepts.

title: Estimate probability using large-scale simulation or real data
short_name: Estimate odds from data
description: Students estimate the probability of a complex or uncertain event (e.g., a hurricane, a sports outcome) by analyzing historical data or running a sophisticated Monte Carlo simulation with many variables, integrating lists, loops, and conditional logic.

title: Analyze bias in AI models trained on biased data
short_name: How does biased data hurt AI?
description: Students learn that AI systems trained on biased datasets produce biased outputs, and can examine examples (e.g., if a training dataset has more images of one gender, the model may perform worse on that gender). They reason about consequences and potential fixes.

title: Evaluate ethical considerations in data-driven decisions
short_name: Is it fair to decide this way?
description: Students examine a real-world scenario where a decision is made using data (e.g., hiring, lending, school admissions, content recommendation) and analyze ethical concerns: Is the data biased? Will the decision harm some groups? What are privacy implications? Should people be informed and given agency?

title: Count words in a sentence
short_name: How many words are in this sentence?
description: Students count the number of words in a short sentence or phrase, recognizing that text is made of discrete units. This is a foundational step toward text data collection and analysis.

title: Find a word in a list
short_name: Search for a word in a list
description: Students locate a target word within a short list of words, introducing the concept of keyword search in its simplest form. This prepares the ground for later computational search.

title: Classify words by first letter
short_name: Sort words by their first letter
description: Students organize a small set of words by their initial letter (e.g., words starting with A, B, C), building categorization skills that relate to data organization.

title: Count how many times a word repeats
short_name: How many times does the word appear?
description: Students count instances of a specific word in a short text, introducing the concept of word frequency in a very concrete way.

title: Create a word list in a project
short_name: Build a list of words in code
description: Students create a list variable and populate it with words (e.g., a list of animals), learning that text can be stored and managed as data within a project.

title: Search a word list for a keyword
short_name: Find a word in your list
description: Students write a script that searches through a word list to find if a target word is present, introducing basic algorithmic search.

title: Count a word's frequency in text
short_name: Count how many times a word appears
description: Students write code that counts how many times a specific word appears in a given text (stored as a variable or list of words), applying iteration and a counter accumulator pattern.

title: Sort words alphabetically
short_name: Arrange words in alphabetical order
description: Students organize a list of words in alphabetical order (by first letter or by letter sequence), reinforcing understanding of text ordering and data organization.

title: Extract the first letter of a word
short_name: Get the first letter of a word
description: Students use text blocks (such as `letter 1 of [word]`) to extract the first character of a word, learning to manipulate strings at a character level.

title: Check if text contains a specific substring
short_name: Does the text contain this word?
description: Students use a `contains` block or write a simple check to determine if a text string includes a substring, extending keyword search to substrings.

title: Ask a question to an AI and receive a response
short_name: Ask ChatGPT a question
description: Students use CreatiCode's ChatGPT block to send a simple text prompt and receive an AI-generated text response, introducing the concept of natural language processing and AI text generation in a beginner‑friendly way.

title: Convert text to uppercase or lowercase
short_name: Change text case
description: Students use text manipulation blocks to convert a string to uppercase or lowercase, learning basic text transformation.

title: Find the length of a text string
short_name: How long is this text?
description: Students use a `length of` block to determine the number of characters in a text string, introducing measurement of text data.

title: Count words in a longer text passage
short_name: How many words in the passage?
description: Students write code to count the number of words in a longer passage (split by spaces), applying string manipulation and counting logic.

title: Use AI to classify text sentiment or topic
short_name: Ask AI to describe text
description: Students write a prompt for ChatGPT that asks the AI to classify text (e.g., "Is this sentence happy or sad?") and process the AI's response, learning basic text classification.

title: Remove spaces or punctuation from text
short_name: Clean up text
description: Students use text blocks or write logic to strip spaces or punctuation from text, learning text preprocessing.

title: Analyze word frequency in a list of words
short_name: Find the most common word
description: Students analyze a list or passage of words to determine which word appears most frequently, combining counting and comparison skills to extract insights from text data.

title: Visualize text data as a word frequency chart
short_name: Show word counts as a chart
description: Students count word frequencies and create a visual representation (bar chart, stamping pattern, or simple graph) to display the data, connecting text analysis to data visualization.

title: Use AI to summarize a text passage
short_name: Ask AI to summarize text
description: Students use a ChatGPT prompt to summarize a longer passage, learning that AI can extract key information from text.

title: Extract keywords or main ideas from text
short_name: Find the main words in text
description: Students use an AI prompt or simple heuristics to identify the most important words in a passage (keywords), learning basic natural language understanding concepts.

title: Split text into words and store in a list
short_name: Break text into words
description: Students use text manipulation blocks to split a passage by spaces into a list of words, a foundational text preprocessing step for many NLP tasks.

title: Find all occurrences of a substring in text
short_name: Find all instances of a word
description: Students write code that locates all instances of a substring within a text and reports their positions or count, extending basic search to complete pattern matching.

title: Classify text with AI into multiple categories
short_name: Sort text into categories with AI
description: Students use ChatGPT with a well‑crafted prompt to classify multiple text samples into predefined categories (e.g., genre, sentiment, topic), learning prompt engineering and structured AI output.

title: Analyze text data and report statistics
short_name: Compute text statistics
description: Students compute statistics on text data, such as average word length, sentence count, or vocabulary diversity, learning to extract quantitative insights from qualitative data.

title: Pre‑process text for analysis
short_name: Prepare text for analysis
description: Students perform multiple preprocessing steps on text (remove punctuation, convert to lowercase, trim spaces, remove common words) to prepare it for analysis or AI processing, learning data cleaning for text.

title: Compute text similarity or comparison
short_name: Compare how similar two texts are
description: Students use AI or string matching logic to assess similarity between two text passages, learning that text similarity can be computed and compared.

title:
Use AI to answer questions based on a text passage

- **Smart Retrieval:** Ask AI questions about text
- **Description:** Students use a ChatGPT prompt that provides context (e.g., a passage) and asks a question about it, learning how AI can retrieve and synthesize information from text.
- **Challenge format:** Coding, question‑answering project. Provided: a passage. Students ask ChatGPT: "Based on this text: [passage], what is [question]?" and process the response. Auto‑grading checks answer validity against expected responses.
- **CSTA:** MS‑PRO‑PF‑01, CAS‑ET‑05 (Emerging technologies in innovative ways).

### T29.G7.04 – Reflect on bias and fairness in text data and AI responses
short_name: Think about bias in text and AI
description: Students examine how text datasets or AI models might reflect or introduce bias, learning critical thinking about text processing and AI fairness.
csta_code: MS‑PRO‑PF‑01, CAS‑ET‑05 (Emerging technologies in innovative ways).

title: Build a keyword search and retrieval system
short_name: Create a keyword search tool
description: Students design a project that takes user input (keywords) and searches a collection of text documents (or passages in a list), returning matching documents. This is a simplified version of real search engines.

title: Analyze sentiment or emotion in multiple texts using AI
short_name: Analyze emotions in text samples
description: Students apply an AI model (via ChatGPT) to analyze sentiment or emotion in a batch of text samples, then aggregate and visualize the results (e.g., how many positive, negative, neutral texts are in the set).

title: Extract entities or relationships from text using AI
short_name: Find names and connections in text
description: Students use AI (ChatGPT) to extract named entities (people, places, organizations) or relationships from text, learning that AI can identify and structure information from unstructured text.

title: Evaluate the ethical implications of text processing and NLP
short_name: Discuss ethics of text AI
description: Students analyze and discuss complex issues: how NLP systems might perpetuate biases, privacy concerns with text collection, and the use of NLP in surveillance or manipulation. They propose mitigations.

title: Describe purposes of computer hardware
short_name: What does each computer part do?
description: Students explain the purpose of common hardware components: display (shows information), keyboard (user input), mouse (user input), system unit (processes/thinks), and speakers (outputs sound). They use accurate terminology.

title: Recognize input and output devices
short_name: Input vs output
description: Students distinguish between devices or parts that let you control a computer (input: keyboard, mouse, microphone, touchscreen) and devices that show or tell you information (output: display, speakers, printer).

title: Understand hardware and software roles
short_name: Hardware vs software
description: Students distinguish between hardware (the physical parts you can touch: computer box, keyboard, mouse, robot body) and software (the programs/instructions that tell them what to do).

title: Recognize that programs run on devices
short_name: Programs run on computers
description: Students understand that programs (apps, games, scripts) run on devices (computers, tablets, robots) and that the device executes the program's instructions to produce the behavior we see or interact with.

title: Justify software for tasks
short_name: Choose the right software for the job
description: Students select and justify an appropriate software tool or app for a given task (e.g., "I would use a word processor to write a story," "I would use a drawing app to paint a picture"). They explain why that software is suitable.

title: Understand input → processing → output
short_name: How computers receive and send information
description: Students learn the basic I/O model: computers receive input (from keyboard, mouse, sensors), process it internally, and produce output (display, sound, movement). They trace simple flows such as "user types letter" → "computer shows letter on screen."

title: Recognize everyday sensors and their purposes
short_name: Sensors in the real world
description: Students identify simple sensors in their environment (motion sensor doors, light sensors controlling classroom lights, thermostats, touchscreens) and describe what each sensor detects and how a device responds.

title: Connect hardware and software in CreatiCode
short_name: Software controls hardware in CreatiCode
description: Students create or trace a simple CreatiCode project where a program (code) makes hardware (a sprite, simulated robot, or connected device) respond. They understand the code→hardware link.

title: Explain hardware–software interaction for I/O
short_name: How hardware and software work together
description: Students explain that hardware provides physical components for input (keyboard receives a keystroke) and output (display shows pixels), while software interprets the input and decides what output to produce. The two work as a system.

title: Identify sensors and predict device responses
short_name: Sensors detect and devices react
description: Students identify sensors in devices they use (camera, microphone, accelerometer, touch sensor, temperature sensor) and predict how the device responds when the sensor detects something (e.g., a camera detects motion → video app records, a touch sensor detects a finger → light turns on).

title: Troubleshoot a simple hardware/software problem
short_name: Fix a broken device
description: Students apply basic troubleshooting steps (checking connections, restarting, trying again) to solve common hardware and software issues (device won't turn on, app crashes, speaker has no sound). They explain what they tried and why.

title: Build a CreatiCode sensor simulation
short_name: Simulate a sensor in code
description: Students create a CreatiCode project where they simulate a sensor (e.g., a "motion sensor" sprite that detects when another sprite is nearby, or a "button" that triggers an action). They use conditionals to check the sensor state and respond.

title: Describe real-world sensor applications
short_name: How sensors work in devices
description: Students describe real examples of sensors embedded in devices they encounter: motion sensor lights, smartphone cameras detecting faces, fitness trackers counting steps, thermostats regulating temperature. They explain what each sensor detects and how the device uses that data.

title: Design a sensor-based system in CreatiCode
short_name: Build a sensor-triggered project
description: Students design a CreatiCode project that simulates a sensor-based system (e.g., a light-activated room, a robot that avoids obstacles, a game where touching a sprite triggers a reward). They use sensor inputs (simulated via conditionals or collision detection) to control outputs.

title: Understand data flow from sensors
short_name: Sensors send data to programs
description: Students understand that sensors generate data (measurements, yes/no readings, positions) that programs read and use to make decisions. They trace a data flow: sensor captures → software reads → software decides action.

title: Troubleshoot sensor or device malfunctions
short_name: Find sensor/device problems
description: Students identify why a sensor-based system might fail (sensor disconnected, sensor blocked, software not reading sensor, wrong response programmed) and propose fixes. They debug at the hardware–software boundary.

title: Apply troubleshooting steps for hardware/software issues
short_name: Fix common computer problems
description: Students learn and practice systematic troubleshooting: checking connections, verifying power, restarting devices, checking for updates, freeing storage, and using accurate terminology (USB, battery, plug, restart, reinstall, etc.). They articulate which step to try first and why.

title: Collect and analyze data from sensors in CreatiCode
short_name: Use sensor data in a program
description: Students create a CreatiCode project that collects data from simulated sensors (e.g., counting how many times a motion sensor is triggered, averaging temperature readings) and use that data in calculations or decisions. They learn that sensor data becomes variable data.

title: Understand how software controls embedded systems
short_name: Software in robots and devices
description: Students understand that embedded systems (robots, smart watches, microcontrollers) run software (firmware, programs) that control their hardware (motors, LEDs, sensors). They can describe how a robot arm, robot vacuum, or drone's program tells the hardware what to do.

title: Design and test a complete sensor system
short_name: Build a sensor system with logic
description: Students design a more complex CreatiCode system combining multiple sensors, conditional logic, and output (e.g., a security system with motion and door sensors, a simple plant-care system with soil moisture detection, a light controller responding to ambient light and time).

title: Describe file systems and storage
short_name: Files, folders, and storage
description: Students understand that data and programs are stored in files and folders on hardware (hard drives, solid-state drives, cloud servers). They can describe file naming conventions, directory structures, and that storage has limits.

title: Differentiate web-based and local software
short_name: Cloud apps vs desktop programs
description: Students distinguish between software that runs locally on a device (offline, stored locally) and web-based apps (run in a browser, data often in the cloud).
