They understand trade-offs: cloud apps are accessible anywhere but need internet; local apps work offline but are device-specific.

title: Apply troubleshooting to identify hardware/software issues
short_name: Diagnose hardware vs software problems
description: Students apply systematic troubleshooting to determine whether a problem is hardware (device broken, connection loose) or software (app crashed, corrupted file) and suggest appropriate fixes for each type.

title: Build a simulated embedded device in CreatiCode
short_name: Program a simulated device
description: Students create a CreatiCode project that simulates an embedded device (robot, smart home controller, game console) with multiple sensors, logic, and outputs responding to sensor data and user input.

title: Understand operating systems and system software
short_name: How operating systems work
description: Students understand that an operating system (Windows, macOS, iOS, Android, Linux) is software that manages hardware resources (CPU, memory, storage, peripherals) and allows other software to run. They can name common operating systems and describe their role in a computing system.

title: Diagnose and resolve complex hardware/software issues
short_name: Troubleshoot complex problems
description: Students apply multi-step troubleshooting to diagnose and resolve complex issues that may involve hardware, software, OS, or user error. They document steps and verify solutions.

title: Understand hardware performance and constraints
short_name: Hardware limits and performance
description: Students understand how hardware specifications (CPU speed, RAM, storage size, screen resolution) affect system performance and capabilities. They can explain why a program might be slow or why a device can't run certain software.

title: Design a more complex simulated system
short_name: Multi-layer system simulation
description: Students design a CreatiCode simulation of a more complex system (e.g., a home automation system with multiple sensors, user controls, and coordinated outputs; a game with multiple sprites each responding to sensors and user input; a data-collecting weather station).

title: Describe computing devices in industry
short_name: Computers and devices in the real world
description: Students research and describe computing devices used in various industries (robots in manufacturing, medical imaging devices, electronic control units in vehicles, sensors in agriculture, smart systems in buildings). They explain how each device combines hardware, software, and sensors to accomplish its purpose.

title: Understand how software is deployed and updated
short_name: Software distribution and updates
description: Students understand that software is developed, tested, packaged, and distributed to devices (app stores, downloads, cloud services), and that updates patch bugs, add features, and improve security. They can explain why updates are important.

title: Apply advanced troubleshooting and system diagnosis
short_name: Advanced system troubleshooting
description: Students apply advanced troubleshooting: checking system logs, managing startup programs, diagnosing network issues, testing hardware components, and considering interactions between hardware, OS, and software. They document findings and propose solutions.

title: Build a comprehensive system simulation
short_name: Full system design and simulation
description: Students design and implement a comprehensive CreatiCode simulation that represents a complete system or device (e.g., a smart home with multiple rooms, devices, sensors, and user controls; an autonomous robot with navigation, obstacle detection, and task execution; a data-logging environmental monitor with multiple sensors and visualization).

title: Messages have a destination
short_name: Sending a message to someone
description: Students understand that a message sent online has a destination (a person, device, or place), and that the message reaches that destination. They explore examples like email, text messages, and in-game communications.

title: Cloud storage saves your work
short_name: Online storage keeps your files safe
description: Students learn that they can save projects or files "in the cloud" (on the internet) instead of only on their own device. The cloud means a far-away computer that stores and protects their work so they can access it from anywhere.

title: Recognize a shared multiplayer moment
short_name: Playing a game with a friend online
description: Students recognize that in multiplayer games, their actions appear on a friend's screen and vice versa. They understand this involves real-time communication between devices over the internet.

title: Break a message into packets
short_name: Messages are sent in pieces
description: Students learn that long messages (like a video or email) are broken into smaller pieces called packets before traveling over the internet. Each packet travels separately and is reassembled at the destination, like a puzzle being mailed in pieces.

title: Data travels on the Internet
short_name: How the internet moves information
description: Students understand that the internet is made up of connected devices (computers, routers, servers) and that information travels along pathways through these devices from one place to another.

title: Recognize client and server roles
short_name: A server stores; a client asks
description: Students learn that the internet uses a client-server model: your device (the client) asks for information from a distant computer (the server). The server stores the information and sends it back. Examples: asking a website for a webpage, or asking a game server for your saved progress.

title: Introduce CreatiCode cloud variables
short_name: Store data in the cloud using CreatiCode
description: Students create a simple variable in CreatiCode and use a cloud block to save it online. They learn that cloud variables are shared across sessions or accessible from anywhere.

title: Understand web apps (local vs cloud)
short_name: Apps on your device vs on the internet
description: Students distinguish between apps installed on their device (local apps) and web apps (apps that run online, like Google Docs or a Scratch project played in a browser). They recognize that web apps need the internet to work.

title: Passwords protect online accounts
short_name: Why passwords are important online
description: Students understand that passwords protect their personal accounts and data. They learn basic password safety: keeping them private, making them strong, and not sharing them.

title: Basic multiplayer setup in CreatiCode
short_name: Create a multiplayer game room
description: Students use CreatiCode's multiplayer blocks to create a game room that another player can join. They input game name, player name, and role, and understand that both players connect to the same game session.

title: Explain how information travels through networks
short_name: Trace a message's journey on the internet
description: Students follow a simple path of how a message travels from one device to another through the internet, naming stages like "sends from client," "travels through routers," "arrives at server," "server sends back," etc.

title: Synchronize data between players
short_name: Both players see the same thing
description: Students understand that in multiplayer games, the game needs to send each player's position or actions to all other players so everyone sees the same game state. This is data synchronization.

title: Join a multiplayer game in CreatiCode
short_name: Connect to a multiplayer game
description: Students use CreatiCode's join-game block to connect to an existing multiplayer game by providing the game name, host name, password, and their own name/role. They understand the connection process.

title: Broadcast a message to all multiplayer players
short_name: Send a message to all players
description: Students use a broadcast block in CreatiCode multiplayer to send a message that all players in the game receive. This might trigger a shared action (e.g., all sprites jump, or a shared sprite appears).

title: Compare local storage vs cloud storage
short_name: Which storage method is better?
description: Students compare saving data locally (on their device) vs in the cloud (online). They recognize trade-offs: local is fast but not accessible elsewhere; cloud is accessible anywhere but requires internet.

title: Design a turn-based multiplayer game
short_name: Create a 2-player turn game
description: Students design a simple turn-based multiplayer game (e.g., tic-tac-toe, rock-paper-scissors) where players take turns sending data that syncs across both screens. They manage game state (whose turn is it? who won?).

title: Handle network delays in games
short_name: Wait for other players
description: Students recognize that messages over the network take time to travel (latency). In a multiplayer game, they might need to wait for other players' data to arrive before updating the game. They add delays or wait blocks as needed.

title: Understand cloud data storage for apps
short_name: Save app data in the cloud
description: Students use CreatiCode cloud blocks to save complex data (scores, game state, user preferences) so that when they reload the app, the data is still there. They distinguish between different cloud storage uses.

title: Explore a familiar web app's client-server architecture
short_name: How a real website works
description: Students choose a familiar website (e.g., YouTube, Google Docs, a game portal) and diagram its client-server interaction. They identify what the client does (display, input) and what the server does (store data, process, send results).

title: Trace a network protocol (HTTP/HTTPS)
short_name: How web requests work
description: Students trace the steps of a typical HTTP or HTTPS request: client sends a request to a server, server processes it, server sends a response, client displays it. They understand this as a request-response cycle.

title: Design a shared leaderboard with cloud data
short_name: Build a multiplayer leaderboard
description: Students use CreatiCode cloud variables to store player scores in a shared leaderboard. Multiple players can add their scores, and all see the same updated list.

title: Understand network delays and game fairness
short_name: Why multiplayer games need to handle latency
description: Students analyze how network delays (latency) affect multiplayer games. A player's action might appear on their screen before others see it, causing unfairness. They discuss strategies to handle this (e.g., server authoritative, client prediction).

title: Evaluate privacy in shared online data
short_name: Who can see your data?
description: Students recognize that cloud data can be accessed by others if not protected. They evaluate privacy concerns: who has access? Is data encrypted? What if the cloud service is hacked?

title: Model a distributed multiplayer game server
short_name: How game servers work
description: Students understand that a multiplayer game uses a central server that receives data from all players and sends updates back. They model the flow: player sends action to server, server broadcasts update to all players.

title: Design a protocol for multiplayer state sync
short_name: Create a message format for multiplayer data
description: Students design a simple protocol (message format) for multiplayer games, specifying what data gets sent (e.g., player_id, x_position, y_position, action). They recognize that a clear protocol keeps all players in sync.

title: Evaluate network topology and efficiency
short_name: Choosing the best network design
description: Students compare different network topologies (star, mesh, peer-to-peer) for multiplayer games. They reason about which is most efficient (fewest hops), most resilient, most secure.

title: Analyze the impact of networked systems on society
short_name: How the internet changed the world
description: Students research and analyze how networked systems (the internet, social media, multiplayer games, cloud storage) have impacted society: positively (connection, information access) and negatively (privacy, addiction, misinformation).

title: Understand TCP/IP and packet routing
short_name: How the internet routes data
description: Students learn about the TCP/IP protocol: how data is split into packets, assigned IP addresses, and routed across the internet via routers. They trace a message's journey from source to destination.

title: Design a secure multiplayer system
short_name: Protect multiplayer games from attacks
description: Students recognize that multiplayer games can be attacked or cheated (e.g., someone spoofing another player, hacking the server). They design defenses: authentication, encryption, server-side validation.

title: Implement data encryption for privacy
short_name: Encrypt data for protection
description: Students understand that sensitive data (passwords, personal info) should be encrypted before sending over the internet. They learn basic encryption ideas: scrambling data so only the intended receiver can read it.

title: Evaluate resilience and redundancy in networks
short_name: How the internet stays up
description: Students learn that the internet is designed with redundancy: multiple paths for data, backup servers, and distributed architecture so that if one part fails, data can still be routed elsewhere.

title: Identify personally identifiable information (PII)
short_name: Know what is private information
description: Students learn that certain information (full name, address, school, phone number, birthday, photos) is private and should be protected. They recognize examples and non‑examples of PII.

title: Choose whom to trust online
short_name: Online friends and strangers
description: Students distinguish between people they know in real life and strangers online, and understand that not all people online are who they say they are. They learn to check with a trusted adult before talking to someone new.

title: Describe why passwords matter
short_name: Passwords keep accounts safe
description: Students understand that passwords prevent others from accessing their accounts and that they should not share their password even with friends or other students.

title: Spot a simple online scam picture
short_name: Recognize obvious tricks online
description: Students see simplified examples of scams (e.g., "You won a prize! Click here!" or "Enter your password to play!") and identify them as "tricks" or "fake."

title: Explain how to keep information private
short_name: Steps to protect personal data
description: Students list or order steps for keeping information safe online (e.g., use a strong password, don't share details with strangers, ask a trusted adult). They understand the "why" for each step.

title: Create a simple strong password
short_name: Build a password with different types of letters
description: Students create a password using a mix of uppercase, lowercase, and numbers (e.g., "Tiger42Blue"). They learn why mixing types makes passwords harder to guess.

title: Recognize a phishing message or fake login
short_name: Spot fake login pages and trick emails
description: Students see examples of phishing emails or fake login screens and identify them as "fake" or "suspicious." They learn that legitimate sites ask for passwords in specific ways and that unsolicited emails asking for passwords are always tricks.

title: List safe sharing practices
short_name: Decide what is okay to share online
description: Students distinguish between safe and unsafe things to share online (e.g., safe: hobby interests, school subject preference; unsafe: home address, phone number, photo without permission).

title: Understand authentication and access levels
short_name: Passwords and permission levels protect accounts
description: Students learn that authentication (proving you are you via password) prevents unauthorized access, and that different users may have different permissions (e.g., a teacher can edit class documents, a student can only view). They understand the relationship between identity and access.

title: Identify and avoid common scams
short_name: Recognize tricks: contests, urgent requests, unknown links
description: Students recognize common scam patterns: fake prizes or contests, urgent language ("Act now!"), requests from unknown sources, and suspicious links. They learn to verify before clicking or responding.

title: Practice secure account logout
short_name: Log out to keep accounts safe
description: Students understand that logging out prevents others from accessing an account if they use the same device. They recognize logout buttons and practice using them.

title: Understand digital footprint and online reputation
short_name: Know what you leave behind online
description: Students learn that what they post, comment, or create online stays and can be seen by others. They understand that photos, posts, and messages create a "digital footprint" and can affect how others see them.

title: Encrypt and decrypt a simple message
short_name: Use cipher or code to hide information
description: Students apply basic encryption (e.g., Caesar cipher, simple substitution) to understand that encryption scrambles information so that only someone with the right "key" can read it. They encrypt and decrypt short messages.

title: Explain why devices need passwords or biometrics
short_name: Protection for phones and computers
description: Students understand that devices (phones, tablets, laptops) should be locked with passwords, PINs, or biometrics (fingerprint, face ID) to prevent unauthorized use if the device is lost or stolen.

title: Adjust privacy settings in an app or platform
short_name: Control who sees your profile or posts
description: Students locate and adjust privacy settings in a simple app or platform (e.g., making a profile private, choosing who can comment, turning off location sharing). They understand that privacy settings give control over personal information.

title: Identify malware or suspicious software signs
short_name: Spot unwanted programs and warnings
description: Students recognize signs of malware or adware (unexpected pop‑ups, slow performance, strange toolbars) and know to tell a trusted adult or avoid downloading suspicious programs.

title: Understand multi‑factor authentication (MFA)
short_name: Two‑step verification for extra security
description: Students learn that multi‑factor authentication (MFA) requires more than just a password (e.g., password + code from email, password + fingerprint). They understand why this is more secure.

title: Monitor account activity for unauthorized access
short_name: Check if your account is being used strangely
description: Students learn to review login history, connected devices, or recent activity in accounts to detect if someone else has accessed them. They understand what normal activity looks like and what might be suspicious.

title: Build secure passwords and remember them (or use a manager)
short_name: Create strong, unique passwords
description: Students create longer, more complex passwords (e.g., with symbols, mixed case, numbers) and learn strategies to remember them (passphrases) or the concept of password managers.

title: Assess privacy and security of a website or app
short_name: Evaluate before you share information
description: Students examine a website or app for trust indicators (HTTPS, privacy policy, "Contact Us" page, reviews/ratings) and decide whether it is safe to use or share information with it.

title: Classify common types of cyberattacks
short_name: Know the main cyberattack types
description: Students learn to categorize common attacks: phishing, malware, ransomware, DDoS, social engineering. They understand the mechanism of each (e.g., phishing tricks you into revealing info, malware installs unwanted code, ransomware locks files until you pay).

title: Recognize social engineering and manipulation tactics
short_name: Spot tricks to manipulate people
description: Students identify social engineering tactics: impersonation, pretexting, baiting, tailgating. They understand that attackers manipulate emotions or trust to gain access or information.

title: Identify vulnerabilities in computing systems
short_name: Find weaknesses that could be exploited
description: Students analyze a scenario or system description to identify potential vulnerabilities (e.g., weak password policy, unencrypted data, outdated software, no multi‑factor auth). They understand that vulnerabilities can be exploited by attackers.

title: Compare cybersecurity and physical security measures
short_name: Understand trade-offs of security measures
description: Students compare different security approaches (e.g., strong password vs. biometrics, frequent login vs. MFA) and evaluate trade‑offs in convenience, cost, and effectiveness.

title: Understand data breaches and their impact
short_name: Know what happens when data is stolen
description: Students understand that a data breach exposes personal or sensitive information, and can lead to identity theft, fraud, or privacy violations. They learn responses to breaches (e.g., change passwords, check accounts, monitor credit).

title: Explain Defense in Depth strategy
short_name: Layers of security protection
description: Students understand that security requires multiple layers: network firewalls, device passwords, multi‑factor auth, encryption, and user education. If one layer fails, others still protect. They can describe each layer and why it matters.

title: Respond to a cybersecurity incident
short_name: What to do if you think you've been hacked
description: Students learn incident response steps: stop using the account, change passwords, check account activity, contact support, scan for malware. They understand the importance of quick action.

title: Evaluate how design decisions affect security
short_name: How design choices impact user experience and security
description: Students analyze how interface design, default settings, or feature choices affect security and user behavior. E.g., "Is it good that sharing is the default? Why?" They understand trade‑offs between ease‑of‑use and security.

title: Identify secure vs. insecure practices in code or systems
short_name: Spot security flaws in programs
description: Students review simple code or system descriptions and identify insecure practices (e.g., storing passwords in plain text, not validating user input, hardcoding secrets). They understand why these are risky.

title: Analyze real-world cybersecurity incident case studies
short_name: Learn from security breaches and attacks
description: Students examine documented cybersecurity incidents (e.g., major data breaches, ransomware attacks) to understand how they happened, what vulnerabilities were exploited, and how they could have been prevented or responded to better.

title: Make informed decisions about privacy settings and data sharing
short_name: Evaluate privacy trade-offs
description: Students critically examine when and with whom to share data, considering company policies, their own comfort, and potential risks. They weigh benefits (e.g., personalization, convenience) against risks (tracking, data sales, breaches).

title: Understand encryption at a deeper level
short_name: How encryption secures data in transit and at rest
description: Students understand that encryption protects data both when stored (at rest) and when transmitted (in transit). They distinguish between different encryption contexts (e.g., HTTPS for web, encrypted email, encrypted hard drives) and why each matters.

title: Evaluate the security of a technology or system
short_name: Assess security features and risks
description: Students comprehensively evaluate a technology (app, website, platform, device) for security features, vulnerabilities, privacy practices, and suitability for a particular use. They provide justified recommendations.

title: Understand ethical implications of cybersecurity decisions
short_name: Weigh ethics in security trade-offs
description: Students reflect on ethical questions: Is monitoring employees ethical? Is encryption that prevents police investigation wrong? Are security requirements that exclude some people fair? They practice nuanced reasoning about conflicting values.

title: Recognize that people and companies create tools
short_name: Tools are created by people
description: Students understand that the apps, websites, and games they use were created by people or teams at companies, and that these creators decide what the tools can do and how they work. This is a pre‑API insight into the idea that tools come from external sources.

title: List benefits and harms of a tool
short_name: Good and bad things about a tool
description: Students discuss or list both positive effects (e.g., "I can talk to friends") and negative effects (e.g., "I spend too much time on it") of a familiar tool they use. This introduces ethical thinking about technology dependencies.

title: Understand that online tools need internet
short_name: Online tools need connection
description: Students recognize that some tools work on a device without connection (e.g., drawing offline) while others need the internet to work (e.g., watching videos online). This introduces the concept of network dependency.

title: Explain what an "app" or "website" is
short_name: Understand apps and websites
description: Students learn that an "app" is software installed on a device that does specific things, while a "website" is accessed through the internet via a browser. They understand that both are tools created to help or entertain people.

title: Describe what data a tool collects (introduce idea)
short_name: Tools collect information about you
description: Students learn that when they use apps or websites, the tool (or the company behind it) collects some information about them—such as their name, what they click on, or how long they use it. This is a gentle introduction to data collection and privacy.

title: Follow a simple login process
short_name: Sign in with a username and password
description: Students practice or describe using a username and password to log into a simple tool or website (e.g., a classroom portal). They understand that login protects their personal data and that a password keeps it safe.

title: Recognize that CreatiCode is a platform
short_name: What is the CreatiCode platform?
description: Students learn that CreatiCode is an online platform—a place where they can create, code, and share projects. The platform provides the tools (blocks, sprites, etc.) they use, and it connects to the internet to save their work and share with others.

title: Use AI text generation (ChatGPT block intro)
short_name: Ask an AI for help with text
description: Students use a ChatGPT block in CreatiCode to send a text request to OpenAI's AI and get a response back into their project. For example, they might ask the AI "Tell me a joke" or "What is photosynthesis?" and display the answer in their project. This is their first direct use of an external API.

title: Understand that external services might not work
short_name: What happens if the internet is down?
description: Students learn that CreatiCode projects that use AI, speech, or the internet might not work if the internet connection is lost or if the external service (like OpenAI or Google Translate) is temporarily down. This introduces the concept of service reliability and dependency.

title: Use speech recognition (voice input)
short_name: Record and transcribe speech
description: Students use CreatiCode's speech recognition blocks to record their voice and convert it to text within their project. They understand that the audio is sent to a speech-to-text service, which returns the recognized text that the project can then use.

title: Use text‑to‑speech (voice output)
short_name: Make a sprite speak with AI voice
description: Students use CreatiCode's AI Speaker block to convert text to spoken audio. They can choose languages and voice styles, and the system generates speech. They learn that a text‑to‑speech service processes their text and returns audio.

title: Search for AI-generated images
short_name: Find or create images with AI
description: Students use CreatiCode's AI image library to search for backdrop and sprite images. They learn that they can search a community library of AI-generated images or create new ones by writing a detailed description. This introduces prompt engineering in a creative context.

title: Understand API key and authentication concept
short_name: What is an API key?
description: Students learn, at a high level, that some external services (like ChatGPT or Google Translate) need a way to identify the user or project accessing them. They understand that an API key is like a password for tools—it proves that the person using the service has permission. CreatiCode handles this behind the scenes, but students should know it exists.

title: Use cloud variables to save data online
short_name: Save data in the cloud
description: Students use CreatiCode's cloud variable blocks to store data (like a player's name or high score) online. They understand that this data persists between sessions—when they close the project and reopen it, the data is still there. Cloud variables enable simple data persistence and sharing across multiple plays.

title: Translate text using an external API
short_name: Translate text with an API
description: Students use a translation block (or Google Translate integration) to convert text from one language to another. They understand that the text is sent to a translation service and the translated result comes back.

title: Understand data flow between tools (diagram)
short_name: Trace how data flows between tools
description: Students trace or diagram how data moves when using external services. For example: "I ask the AI a question (data out) → OpenAI processes it (external service) → My project receives the answer (data back in)." This is a conceptual skill building understanding of request-response cycles.

title: Recognize benefits and risks of using external services
short_name: Pros and cons of using external APIs
description: Students list or discuss advantages (e.g., "I can add voice without building it myself") and disadvantages (e.g., "If the service goes down, my project stops working") of relying on external APIs and services. This builds critical thinking about technological dependencies.

title: Trace data sent to external services
short_name: Understand what data leaves your project
description: Students examine a CreatiCode project that uses external services (like ChatGPT or speech recognition) and identify what data is being sent from their project to the external service. For example, "When I use speech recognition, my audio is sent to Google/OpenAI." They consider what personal information might be included.

title: Evaluate privacy of using external services
short_name: Think about privacy when using APIs
description: Students learn that when a CreatiCode project uses external services, some of their data (like typed text, voice, images) is sent to those services. They evaluate privacy policies or think about what happens to that data. Do they feel comfortable sharing? Should there be safeguards?

title: Use multiplayer blocks to sync game state
short_name: Sync data in a multiplayer game
description: Students use CreatiCode's multiplayer blocks to create a simple networked game where two players' actions are synchronized. They broadcast sprite positions or game state to all players via the multiplayer server, understanding that the server is an external service that stores and relays data.

title: Identify and handle API errors gracefully
short_name: Handle broken connections or failed requests
description: Students learn that API calls can fail (no internet, service down, invalid request). They design or improve a project to handle these failures gracefully—e.g., showing a message "Can't reach AI service, try again later" instead of crashing silently.

title: Compare cloud storage solutions
short_name: Understand different ways to save data
description: Students compare cloud variables in CreatiCode with other ways to save data online (e.g., Google Drive, cloud databases, email). They understand trade-offs: ease of use vs. functionality, security, privacy, and cost. This builds understanding of platform choice and data stewardship.

title: Trace a multi-service project architecture
short_name: Understand a project's external dependencies
description: Given a more complex CreatiCode project that uses multiple external services (e.g., ChatGPT, speech, multiplayer, cloud variables), students map out and describe which services it relies on, what data flows between them, and what would break if each service failed.

title: Evaluate algorithmic bias in AI services
short_name: Recognize bias in AI tools
description: Students learn that AI services (like ChatGPT, translation, or image generation) can have biases. For example, ChatGPT might give different answers based on how a question is phrased, or an image generator might produce stereotyped results. Students think about impacts and responsibility.

title: Design for offline resilience
short_name: Make a project work without internet
description: Students design or modify a CreatiCode project to work as much as possible even when the internet is down or external services fail. For example, storing some data locally, caching API responses, or offering offline alternatives. This builds thinking about robustness.

title: Analyze the business model of a platform
short_name: How do platforms make money?
description: Students learn that platforms like CreatiCode, YouTube, or ChatGPT have business models: some are free with ads, some charge subscriptions, and some collect and sell user data. Students analyze the trade-offs and ethical implications.

title: Evaluate environmental impact of cloud services
short_name: Cloud services and environmental cost
description: Students learn that cloud services (where data and computations happen on distant servers) require significant electricity and infrastructure (data centers). They evaluate the environmental cost of using these services and think about sustainability.

title: Consider digital equity and access
short_name: Not everyone can access the same platforms
description: Students recognize that access to platforms and APIs is not universal—students in low-income areas, rural regions, or developing countries may lack reliable internet. They think about implications: What happens to their project if someone doesn't have internet? How should platform creators think about equity?

title: Plan a responsible project using external services
short_name: Design an ethical project with APIs
description: Students design a new project concept that uses external services (AI, cloud data, multiplayer) and explicitly plan for privacy, data security, bias, and accessibility. They write or present a brief design document considering these concerns.

title: Explore computing contributions from different cultures
short_name: People from different places invented technology
description: Students learn that people from many different cultures, countries, and backgrounds helped create and shape computing technologies. They explore the idea that computing is a global story, not just one person or place, building inclusive awareness early.

title: Before and after a computing technology
short_name: How did life change with this technology?
description: Students compare life before and after a specific computing technology was invented (before/after cameras on phones; before/after email; before/after video games). They recognize that technologies change how people live, work, and play.

title: Name a computing inventor
short_name: Who invented this technology?
description: Students learn and recall the names of some famous inventors or pioneers in computing (e.g., Steve Jobs, Bill Gates, Ada Lovelace, Alan Turing, Grace Hopper, or others reflecting diverse backgrounds). They associate names with their contributions to computing.

title: Draw or describe an invention
short_name: What would you invent to solve a problem?
description: Students think about a real problem they face (finding their toys, organizing their schedule, playing with friends) and imagine a computing device or tool that could help. They sketch or describe their invention, beginning to see computing as a response to human needs.

title: Compare daily life before and after a technology
short_name: Life changed when we got this technology
description: Students examine a specific computing innovation (computers in schools, smartphones, the internet, video calling, etc.) and describe tangible changes in how people work, learn, or socialize. They develop the concept of "then vs now."

title: Identify what a technology helps people do
short_name: What is this technology used for?
description: Students are shown a computing technology or tool and explain what tasks or goals it helps people accomplish (a calculator helps with math, a camera app helps capture memories, email helps people communicate). This links technology to purpose.

title: Good and not-so-good impacts of a technology
short_name: How has this technology helped and hurt?
description: Students begin to think about both positive and negative impacts of a technology. For example, smartphones help people stay connected but can also distract from face-to-face time. This introduces nuance and critical thinking about computing.

title: Timeline of a computing invention
short_name: Put events in order: the history of X
description: Students are given 3–5 key events or milestones in the history of a computing technology (e.g., first computer, first laptop, first smartphone) in scrambled order and must arrange them in chronological order, reinforcing timeline thinking.

title: Research computing in your community
short_name: How has computing changed our town or school?
description: Students research and describe how a computing technology or innovation has affected their local community (school uses computers for attendance, the library has digital catalogs, local businesses use websites, etc.). They see computing as part of their world.

title: How does technology respond to what people need?
short_name: Inventions solve real problems
description: Students examine historical examples where computing innovations were created to solve specific problems (email to communicate across distance, digital maps to navigate, text-to-speech to help people with reading difficulties). They understand design as a response to human need.

title: Compare how technology was different 50+ years ago
short_name: Computing 50 years ago vs today
description: Students research or are shown what computing looked like decades ago (room-sized computers, punch cards, no internet, no smartphones) and compare it to today. They recognize massive change and progress.

title: Invent a solution to a problem
short_name: Design a new computing tool for a problem
description: Students identify a real problem they or their community faces and design or sketch a computing solution, applying the idea that computing tools are invented to meet needs.

title: Trace the evolution of a technology
short_name: How has one technology changed over time?
description: Students research and create a detailed timeline showing how one technology evolved (e.g., cell phones: 1973 Motorola brick → 1990s feature phones → 2000s smartphones → today's AI-enabled phones). They identify key milestones and reasons for change.

title: Identify pioneers from diverse backgrounds
short_name: Computing pioneers from around the world
description: Students learn about computing pioneers from diverse cultures, genders, ethnicities, and regions (Ada Lovelace, Alan Turing, Grace Hopper, Hedy Lamarr, Katherine Johnson, Euclid Lantern, and others). They recognize that computing history is global and inclusive.

title: Examine positive and negative societal impacts
short_name: What are the good and bad effects of a technology?
description: Students investigate a computing technology and articulate both positive impacts (e.g., social media enables connection) and negative impacts (e.g., social media can be addictive or spread misinformation). They develop balanced, critical perspective.

title: Unintended consequences of innovation
short_name: What problems did the technology create?
description: Students explore how a computing innovation, while solving one problem, sometimes created new challenges (e.g., cars improved transportation but increased pollution; the internet enabled communication but also cyberbullying). They think critically about side effects.

title: Analyze how a computing innovation changed society
short_name: How did this invention reshape the world?
description: Students examine a major computing innovation (the transistor, the microprocessor, the graphical user interface, the web, smartphones, AI) and explain how it fundamentally changed the way people lived, worked, learned, or communicated. They recognize computing as a driver of social change.

title: Limitations of old technologies
short_name: Why did old technology stop being used?
description: Students examine why certain computing technologies became obsolete (floppy disks, dial-up internet, desktop-only computers) and identify limitations that newer technologies overcame (slow speed, small storage, lack of portability). They understand technological progress through replacement cycles.

title: Contributions of diverse pioneers
short_name: Pioneers who shaped computing from many backgrounds
description: Students research and present on multiple computing pioneers, deliberately including women, people of color, and non-Western contributors whose work is often overlooked. They challenge narrow narratives and recognize global contributions (Ada Lovelace, Grace Hopper, Hedy Lamarr, Alan Kay, Guido van Rossum, and others from diverse backgrounds).

title: Computing in response to global challenges
short_name: How does computing help solve big problems?
description: Students examine how computing technologies have been developed to address large societal or environmental challenges (medical imaging for disease detection, models for climate prediction, apps for pandemic response, GPS for navigation and disaster response). They see computing as a tool for public good.

title: How challenges led to computing innovations
short_name: Problems that led to computing breakthroughs
description: Students examine specific historical or social challenges that motivated computing innovations. For example, World War II code-breaking drove computer development; massive data analysis needs inspired databases; accessibility needs drove assistive computing tools. They understand computing as a response to urgent human problems.

title: Roles of different groups in advancing computing
short_name: Who contributed to building computing technologies?
description: Students investigate how computing progress involved multiple actors: mathematicians and logicians developing theory, engineers building hardware, programmers writing software, entrepreneurs commercializing, and users driving demand. They recognize computing as a collaborative, multi-disciplinary endeavor.

title: Intended and unintended impacts of historical technologies
short_name: Good and bad outcomes of computing breakthroughs
description: Students analyze a historical computing technology for its intended benefits and unintended harms (e.g., databases enable efficient business but also enable surveillance; the internet enables information sharing but also spreads disinformation). They develop sophisticated thinking about technology and society.

title: How a historical practice led to modern ethical concerns
short_name: From the past to ethical issues today
description: Students trace a computing practice from history to a present-day ethical concern. For example, early data collection practices without consent → modern privacy violations; early AI systems trained on biased data → modern algorithmic bias; early surveillance tools → modern privacy erosion. They see ethics as rooted in historical choices.

title: Major eras of computing history
short_name: Computing eras: mainframes to AI
description: Students learn and distinguish major eras in computing history: mechanical computing (abacus, Babbage's difference engine), electronic/mainframe era (1940s–1960s), personal computer era (1970s–1980s), internet/web era (1990s–2000s), mobile and cloud era (2010s), and AI era (2020s). They understand how each era introduced different capabilities and challenges.

title: Key figures and their contributions
short_name: Notable people who shaped computing
description: Students research and report on multiple notable computing figures from diverse backgrounds and eras (Charles Babbage, Ada Lovelace, Alan Turing, Grace Hopper, Steve Jobs, Bill Gates, Linus Torvalds, Sheryl Sandberg, etc.). They understand computing progress through the lens of individual and collaborative achievement.

title: Comparing historical computing innovations
short_name: How different innovations shaped the world
description: Students compare two or more historical computing innovations (e.g., transistor vs integrated circuit; TCP/IP vs HTML; graphical user interface vs command line) in terms of their effects on computing capabilities, accessibility, and society. They analyze both similarities and differences in impact.

title: Environmental and social impacts of computing evolution
short_name: Computing's effects on the environment and society
description: Students examine how computing technology expansion has affected the environment (e-waste, energy consumption of data centers, manufacturing pollution) and society (job displacement, digital divides, inequality, benefits of automation). They develop critical perspective on progress and trade-offs.

title: Policies and legislation shaping computing
short_name: Laws and rules that guide computing
description: Students examine policies and legislation that have shaped computing development and use: intellectual property laws, data protection regulations (GDPR, CCPA), accessibility requirements (Section 508), content moderation rules, AI governance proposals, etc. They understand that computing evolves within a regulatory and legal context.

title: Historical disparities in computing access and benefits
short_name: Who benefits from computing? Who doesn't?
description: Students analyze historical patterns showing how computing benefits and access have been distributed unequally across groups (gender disparities in tech careers, digital divides by geography and socioeconomic status, bias in AI training data, underrepresentation of women and people of color in computing). They connect history to present-day inequities.

title: Computing innovations responding to societal needs
short_name: How innovations solve real-world problems
description: Students research and analyze multiple computing innovations developed in response to specific societal needs or crises: medical computing for diagnosis and treatment, financial computing for transactions, educational technology for remote learning, disaster response apps, etc. They see computing as pragmatic problem-solving.

title: Futures thinking: Computing trends and implications
short_name: Where is computing headed and what matters?
description: Students examine current trends in computing (AI, quantum computing, biotechnology integration, internet of things, decentralization) and speculate about future implications for society, environment, work, and daily life. They develop forward-looking critical thinking.

title: List both good and bad effects of a technology
short_name: Good and bad sides of apps
description: Students name both positive effects (e.g., learning, talking to friends) and negative effects (e.g., too much time, tiredness, lost focus) of a common app or device, recognizing that technologies have mixed impacts.

title: Predict what happens if you play too long
short_name: What happens if you play all day?
description: Students hypothesize or discuss consequences of spending too much screen time on a game (e.g., missing homework, tired eyes, less playtime outside, missing dinner).

title: Recognize that games are made by people
short_name: People make games
description: Students understand that every game or app they enjoy was designed and built by people (game makers, artists, programmers) and that someone made choices about how it looks and works.

title: Decide when to use a device and when not to
short_name: When is it time to use a device?
description: Students practice making reasonable choices about when to use a device (e.g., homework time, quiet time) versus when to do other things (e.g., eat, play outside, sleep).

title: Compare life before and after a technology
short_name: Life before and after a technology
description: Students compare how people did a task before a computing technology existed and how they do it now, noticing the changes and whether life became easier, faster, or different in other ways (e.g., before video calls vs. video calls now, or before digital maps vs. GPS).

title: Brainstorm how a new technology could help
short_name: How could we use a device to solve a problem?
description: Students propose ways that a new or existing technology could solve a real problem in their school or community (e.g., "A robot could help carry heavy books," "An app could remind people to drink water").

title: Identify unintended problems from a technology
short_name: Unexpected bad effects of a technology
description: Students recognize that a technology made to help can also cause problems that were not originally intended (e.g., video games are fun but can be addictive; social media helps friends connect but can spread false information).

title: Describe how different communities use technology differently
short_name: Not everyone uses technology the same way
description: Students recognize that different groups of people (families, communities, regions) may use technology in different ways or have different access to it, and that this affects how it impacts them.

title: Evaluate whether a technology choice is good for you
short_name: Is this a good choice for you?
description: Students evaluate whether using a particular technology suits their current needs and the likely consequences (e.g., "Is it a good idea to play a video game right before bed?" or "Should I use a voice app to do my homework when I need to learn?"). They weigh benefits and harms.

title: Identify both intended and unintended consequences of a technology
short_name: Expected and unexpected effects of technology
description: Students systematically list what a technology was intended to do and what unintended side effects it might have, recognizing that designers sometimes cannot predict all consequences.

title: Recognize AI and smart tools
short_name: What is artificial intelligence?
description: Students identify examples of AI or "smart" technologies in their lives (e.g., a voice assistant that understands questions, a camera that recognizes faces, a game that learns your skill level) and understand that these are tools that are taught to make decisions, not tools with human-like thoughts.

title: Examine why people adopt new technologies
short_name: Why do people choose new technologies?
description: Students think about the reasons people adopt or use new technologies (e.g., saving time, solving a problem, following friends, ease of use) and consider whether those reasons are helpful or potentially harmful.

title: Trace the history of a technology over time
short_name: How has a technology changed?
description: Students research or trace how a specific technology (e.g., phones, cameras, games, search engines) has evolved over time, noticing that technologies are not static and that changes respond to needs and user feedback.

title: Analyze roles of different people in creating a technology
short_name: Many people work together to make a technology
description: Students recognize that a single app, game, or device requires people from many fields: programmers, artists, designers, sound engineers, testers, marketers, etc. Each person has a role in determining how the final product affects users.

title: Evaluate an app or game for fairness and bias
short_name: Is this technology fair for everyone?
description: Students examine whether a technology, game, or app is fair and accessible to different groups (e.g., people with different abilities, languages, incomes, backgrounds). They identify potential biases or barriers.

title: Design a responsible technology feature
short_name: How would you make a game more responsible?
description: Students propose features or changes to an existing app or game to make it healthier or fairer (e.g., adding a "take a break" reminder, allowing players to pause, offering difficulty levels for different abilities, removing stereotypes).

title: Analyze how screen time affects learning and behavior
short_name: How does screen time affect us?
description: Students investigate research or personal observations about how extended screen use affects attention, sleep, social skills, physical health, and academic performance. They reason about causal relationships and tradeoffs.

title: Examine how AI and algorithms make decisions
short_name: How do AI systems decide what you see?
description: Students understand that AI systems in social media, recommendation apps, and search engines use algorithms to decide what information, ads, or content to show each user, and that these decisions can influence behavior and beliefs.

title: Evaluate environmental impacts of technology
short_name: How does making devices affect the environment?
description: Students learn that producing, transporting, and disposing of computing devices requires energy, materials, and water, and can cause pollution. They discuss tradeoffs between the benefits of technology and environmental cost.

title: Create a personal technology use plan
short_name: Design your own healthy tech habits
description: Students set personal goals and create a plan for balanced technology use, considering school, homework, social time, outdoor activity, and sleep. They reflect on what balance means for them.

title: Compare an emerging technology to older versions
short_name: Compare old technology to new technology
description: Students contrast an emerging technology (e.g., AI chatbots, AR filters) with the older technology it replaces or relates to, examining differences in features, speed, accessibility, and how they change the user experience across different communities.

title: Evaluate design decisions in a technology
short_name: How do design choices affect different users?
description: Students analyze how specific design decisions in a technology (e.g., interface color, game difficulty, notification frequency, language options) affect different groups of users differently, particularly underrepresented or marginalized groups.

title: Trace how a technology transformed a process
short_name: How did a technology change the way people work?
description: Students research how a technology (e.g., spreadsheets, email, video conferencing, online shopping) has fundamentally changed how a profession, business, or activity operates, examining both benefits and disruptions.

title: Identify expertise needed for an emerging technology
short_name: What experts created this technology?
description: Students recognize that emerging technologies depend on knowledge from multiple fields (e.g., biology for medical AI, art for design, psychology for user experience, ethics for fairness) and that collaboration across disciplines is essential.

title: Analyze unintended systemic impacts of a technology
short_name: How does one technology change everything?
description: Students examine how a single technology can create ripple effects across society (e.g., smartphones enabling communication but also job displacement in certain sectors, social media enabling connection but also affecting mental health). They map systems and second-order effects.

title: Evaluate equity and access across communities
short_name: Do all communities benefit equally from a technology?
description: Students research or analyze whether access to and benefits from a technology (e.g., broadband, AI tools, smartphones) are equally distributed, and what happens when some communities lack access.

title: Examine the environmental life cycle of a technology
short_name: The full environmental impact of a device
description: Students trace the full environmental lifecycle of a computing device: extraction of materials, manufacturing, shipping, use, and disposal/recycling. They quantify or estimate the carbon footprint and waste.

title: Propose a technology solution with ethical considerations
short_name: Design a responsible technology solution
description: Students propose a new technology (or improve an existing one) to solve a real problem while considering potential negative effects, equity, environmental impact, and privacy. They justify their approach.

title: Evaluate an emerging technology from multiple perspectives
short_name: Who benefits and who is harmed by a new technology?
description: Students evaluate a specific emerging technology (e.g., facial recognition, autonomous vehicles, AI in hiring) through the lens of different stakeholders (developers, users, workers affected by job loss, marginalized communities, environment) and explain how different groups have conflicting interests.

title: Analyze policy and regulation of an emerging technology
short_name: Should governments regulate this technology?
description: Students examine how governments and organizations regulate or should regulate emerging technologies (e.g., data privacy laws, AI transparency requirements, content moderation), weighing innovation, safety, freedom, and fairness.

title: Investigate personal data collection and privacy
short_name: What data do companies collect about you?
description: Students investigate what personal data apps and websites collect about them (location, behavior, preferences), how it is used (targeted ads, training AI), and what privacy risks this creates.

title: Create a presentation on responsible AI use
short_name: Communicate about AI impacts and responsibility
description: Students research an AI application (e.g., chatbots, image recognition, recommendation systems) and create a presentation or essay for peers addressing: what it does, who created it, intended benefits, known harms or biases, ethical concerns, and what responsible use looks like.

title: Many different jobs use computers
short_name: List jobs that use computers
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students name or recognize a variety of jobs and professions (scientists, teachers, artists, musicians, builders, store workers) that use computing technology in their work. They expand their awareness beyond typical "computer" jobs to see computing is everywhere.

title: Technology brings both good things and problems
short_name: Identify benefits and harms of a technology
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students observe examples of a technology (smartphone, video game, social media, educational app) in action and recognize that while it helps people, it can also cause problems (screen time, unfairness, lost playtime). They begin to think about tradeoffs.

title: Listening is important in group work
short_name: Show you are listening to your team
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students practice active listening when peers explain ideas—making eye contact, waiting their turn, and responding appropriately. They understand that listening helps a group work together better.

title: Share your ideas and ask questions
short_name: Speak up and ask in group projects
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students gain confidence in speaking their ideas and asking questions during group work, even if they are unsure. They learn that everyone's ideas matter and that asking "Why?" or "How?" helps the group.

title: New tech to solve a problem
short_name: Imagine a technology that solves a problem
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students observe a simple problem (kids lose toys, hard to find things, need to stay warm) and hypothesize how a new or improved technology could help solve it. They develop the habit of thinking "How could a tool or computer help?"

title: Everyone gets a turn and a voice
short_name: Make sure all voices are heard
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students practice strategies to include everyone in group work: asking quiet members for input, rotating who speaks first, taking turns with the computer, making time for different ideas. They experience or observe groups where everyone contributes.

title:
Tell what went well and what to improve

- **Description:** Students reflect on a group project or collaboration and identify what worked well and what could be better next time. They practice giving and receiving friendly feedback.
- **Challenge format:** Concept, structured reflection. After a short collaborative task in CreatiCode, students complete a simple form: "One thing we did well: _____. One thing to improve: _____." Auto‑grading checks for specific, constructive feedback using keywords.
- **CSTA:** PRO‑PM (Inclusive Collaboration: reflection on collaborative work).

### T36.G2.04 – Show your project to others
short_name: Present a project to the class
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students prepare to share a completed CreatiCode project with peers or teachers, learning to explain what their project does, what they built, and what they learned. This is a first step toward project communication.
csta_code: PRO‑PM (Inclusive Collaboration: reflection on collaborative work).

title: Why do people choose to use (or not use) a technology?
short_name: Explain a choice about using technology
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students analyze real or hypothetical scenarios where a person chooses whether to use a technology (a smartphone, a gaming console, AI tool, video call) and explain the reasons: need, interest, consequences. They explore the idea that our choices about technology affect ourselves and others.

title: Fair and unfair in algorithms
short_name: Spot unfairness in how a computer decides
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students recognize that a computer program (algorithm) can treat people differently or unfairly if not designed carefully. For example, a recommendation engine might only suggest certain types of games to boys or girls, or a filter might miss some faces. They begin to think critically about algorithm fairness.

title: Document your project so others understand
short_name: Write comments to explain your code
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students add simple comments or descriptions to their CreatiCode projects so that someone else (a classmate, teacher, or future self) can understand what each part does. They learn that clear communication improves the quality of their work.

title: Work together fairly: roles and responsibilities
short_name: Assign and explain team roles
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students practice assigning roles in a group project (idea person, builder, tester, presenter) so that everyone has a job and knows what they are responsible for. They understand that clear roles reduce conflict and help the team succeed.

title: Intended and unintended consequences
short_name: Predict good and bad effects of a technology
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students investigate how a technology (social media, educational software, automation, AI tool) was designed to help people but can also cause unintended harm: making people lonely, spreading misinformation, losing jobs, violating privacy. They practice systems thinking—understanding that one change can ripple.

title: Is this data or algorithm fair to everyone?
short_name: Identify bias in data or a decision rule
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students examine simple datasets or rules and spot patterns that might be unfair or biased. For example, a dataset of "successful coders" that includes mostly boys, or an algorithm that approves loans at different rates for different groups. They learn to question: "Who benefits? Who might be harmed?"

title: Create a presentation about your project
short_name: Make slides or a poster to show your work
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students create a presentation (using CreatiCode presentation tools, slides, or poster format) that explains their project: what it does, how they built it, what was hard, and what they learned. They practice organizing information for an audience.

title: Ethics: Is my project respectful?
short_name: Check if your project treats people fairly
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students reflect on a project they built or are planning: Does it include characters from different backgrounds? Does it stereotype anyone? Could it harm someone? They develop an internal ethical checklist when making creative computational work.

title: What are the limits of this technology?
short_name: Explain what a technology cannot do
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students analyze a real technology and articulate its limitations: what it can't do well, who it doesn't help, what problems it doesn't solve. They develop critical, nuanced thinking about technology as a tool with boundaries, not a universal solution.

title: People from different jobs work together
short_name: Show how different experts collaborate with computing
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students explore real examples where professionals from different fields (engineer, artist, biologist, teacher, doctor) work together using computing to solve a problem or create something. They see that computing bridges many disciplines and career paths.

title: Explain your project design choices
short_name: Document why you made certain choices
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students write or present an explanation of the major design decisions in a completed CreatiCode project: why they chose certain characters, colors, rules, or features; how they thought about making it fair, fun, or accessible; what they would change if they had more time.

title: Respectful feedback and revision
short_name: Give and receive helpful feedback
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students practice giving constructive criticism ("I liked ___ because ___. A suggestion: ___") and receiving feedback without defensiveness. They revise a project based on peer feedback, learning that iteration improves quality and that respect matters in critique.

title: Recognize bias in data and algorithms
short_name: Spot and analyze bias in real systems
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students examine real or realistic examples of bias in data-driven systems: hiring algorithms that discriminate, facial recognition that works better for some skin tones, recommendation systems that exclude certain groups. They analyze why bias happens and propose improvements.

title: How computational thinking helps in different careers
short_name: Explain how professionals use CS to solve problems
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students research professionals in various fields (medicine, environmental science, entertainment, business, sports) and explain how those professionals use computational thinking (breaking problems into steps, finding patterns, testing solutions) to do their work better.

title: Ethics in a career: dilemmas and decisions
short_name: Discuss ethical challenges in computing jobs
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students explore scenarios where computing professionals face ethical dilemmas: Should we collect this data? Should this AI be deployed? Is this privacy violation worth the convenience? They practice reasoning through competing values and considering impacts on diverse groups.

title: Inclusive design: consider diverse users
short_name: Design for people with different abilities and needs
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students apply inclusive design principles to a project: considering users with different physical abilities, language backgrounds, learning styles, and cultural contexts. They understand that thoughtful design makes technology better for everyone.

title: How tech transforms industries and jobs
short_name: Analyze how technology changes careers and industries
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students examine a specific industry (agriculture, manufacturing, healthcare, entertainment) and trace how computing and automation have changed the jobs available, the skills needed, and the opportunities for workers. They consider both positive changes (new careers) and challenges (job displacement, need for retraining).

title: Ethical evaluation of emerging technologies
short_name: Evaluate a new technology for ethics and fairness
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students select an emerging technology (AI, VR, IoT, blockchain, autonomous vehicles, facial recognition) and conduct a thorough ethical evaluation: What is it designed to do? Who benefits? Who might be harmed? Is it fair? Is it accessible? What policies should govern it?

title: Lead a team project with clear communication
short_name: Manage a collaborative project from start to finish
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students take on a leadership role in a multi-person, multi-week CreatiCode project. They practice planning (breaking tasks into steps, assigning roles), communicating clearly (holding meetings, writing updates), managing time and conflicts, and presenting results professionally.

title: Reflect on fairness in your team and project
short_name: Assess your team's inclusivity and your project's fairness
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students reflect on two aspects: (1) Did our team work fairly—did everyone contribute, were decisions made inclusively, was credit given? (2) Is our project inclusive and fair—does it include diverse characters, avoid stereotypes, work well for people with different abilities?

title: Analyze societal impacts of computing technologies
short_name: Examine how a technology impacts society and inequality
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students conduct a research project analyzing how a widely used technology (social media, smartphones, AI assistants, cloud services, surveillance systems, e-commerce) impacts different groups of people, considering access, equity, environmental effects, cultural impacts, and power dynamics. They present nuanced, evidence-based arguments.

title: Explore a computing career pathway
short_name: Investigate a specific computing career and its requirements
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students deep-dive into a computing-related career of interest (game developer, data scientist, cybersecurity specialist, AI researcher, software engineer, digital artist, tech policy analyst, etc.), researching education requirements, skills needed, salary range, daily tasks, and how computing interacts with their values and interests. They assess fit with their own aspirations.

title: Design a solution with ethics at the center
short_name: Create a project that solves a problem fairly
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students identify a real problem or need (accessibility barrier, environmental challenge, educational gap, social issue) and design a CreatiCode project or prototype that attempts to solve it while explicitly considering: Who is this for? What biases might we introduce? How do we include diverse perspectives in the design? How will we know if it actually helps?

title: Communicate professionally about your work
short_name: Present your project professionally to diverse audiences
topic_name: Ethics, Careers, Collaboration & Communication in CS
description: Students develop a polished presentation or documentation of a substantial project suitable for multiple audiences (classmates, teachers, parents, competition judges, potential employers). They practice adapting their communication to audience, using technical vocabulary appropriately, and conveying both technical details and broader impact.
